Category B: Initial environmental examination done.  
 
The Second Urban Primary Health Care Project (the Project) will safeguard 
the  environment  by  upgrading  clinical  waste  management  (CWM)  systems 
to  meet  Government  standards  for  hazardous  medical  waste  management 
and to comply with the environment policy of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). Newly constructed and upgraded civil works will include capital and 
recurrent investments to improve CWM. 
 
The  Project  will  help  ensure  the  delivery  of  a  package  of  preventive, 
promotive,  and  curative  health  services  to  the  poor  in  all  the  six  city 
corporations—Dhaka,  Chittagong,  Khulna,  Rajshahi,  Sylhet,  and  Barisal—
and five municipalities—Bogra, Comilla, Sirajgonj, Madhabdi and Savar. The 
services  will  be  designed  to  reduce  child  and  maternal  mortality  and 
morbidity, and help the country achieve the Millennium Development Goals 
(MDGs). The Project will continue to contract out primary health care (PHC) 
services  to  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  through  partnership 
agreements that were pioneered under the first Urban Primary Health Care 
Project  (UPHCP-I).  Free  and  easily  accessible  PHC  services  will  be  made 
available to the poor. The Project will ensure pro-poor targeting by requiring 
that  at  least  30%  of  the  preventive,  promotive,  and  curative  services  are 
provided  free  for  the  poor.  User  fees  will  be  charged  to  people  who  can 
afford them. Nutritional supplements will be given to moderately to severely 
malnourished  women  and  children.  The  Project  will support  construction  of 
64  health  facilities,  upgrading  of  4,  and  purchase  of  12  apartments  and/or 
buildings for PHC facilities in Dhaka city corporation. Community-run latrines 
and  community-based  solid-waste  disposal  will  be  piloted  to  improve 
environmental health, and CWM will be supported.  
 
Until recently, urban PHC has been a neglected subsector in Bangladesh as 
in  most  other  South  Asian  countries.  The  urban  population  has  been 
growing  rapidly,  mostly  because  of  rural–urban  migration  by  the  poor  and 
the  vulnerable.  The  absolute  number  of  poor  urban  households  is 
increasing. Studies have shown that the health indicators of the urban poor 
are  worse  than  those  of  the  rural  poor  because  of  poorer  living  conditions, 
and  limited  urban  PHC.  Failure  to  provide  urban  PHC  can  have  serious 
negative  consequences  beyond  urban  areas  because  infectious  diseases 
can spread from urban to rural areas. Rapidly growing urban slums without

The Project will build on the gains of UPHCP-I, and strengthen the pro-poor 
focus, nutrition provision, and project implementation.  
 
A $10-million Asian Development Fund grant will support various HIV/AIDS 
and infectious disease control activities.  Grant financing can be justified at 
country and project levels. The Project is closely aligned with Bangladesh’s 
poverty  reduction  strategy,  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program,  ADB’s 
Partnership  Agreement  on  Poverty  Reduction  with  the  Government  of 
Bangladesh (2000), and ADB’s commitment to reducing poverty and helping 
developing member countries achieve the MDGs. More than half the project 
base costs address infectious disease and HIV/AIDS control. 
 
The Project will improve the health status of the urban population, especially 
of the poor, in six city corporations and five municipalities. At least 30% of all 
the  services  provided  under  the  Project  will  be  targeted  at  poor  people 
earning  less  than  Taka  700  per  month  (the  poor).  The  specific  project 
objectives  are  to  improve:  (i)  access  to  and  use  of  urban  PHC  services  in 
the  project  area,  with  a  particular  focus  on  extending  provision  to  the 
poorest;  (ii)  the  quality  of  urban  PHC  services  in  the  project  area;  and  (iii) 
the cost-effectiveness, efficiency, and institutional and financial sustainability 
of PHC to meet the needs of the urban poor. 
 

 
Cost Estimates  The total project cost, including physical and price contingencies, and taxes 
and  duties,  is  estimated  to  be  $90.0  million  equivalent.  Of  this  amount, 
$4.3 million equivalent (5%) is the foreign exchange cost, and $85.7 million 
equivalent (95%) is the local currency cost.

The Government of Sweden through the Swedish International Development 
Cooperation  Agency  (Sida)  will  provide  a  $5-million  grant,  and  the 
Government of the United Kingdom through the Department for International 
Development (DFID) will provide a $25-million grant both to be administered 
by  ADB.  The  United  Nations  Population  Fund  (UNFPA)  will  cofinance  the 
Project  through  a  $2-million  grant,  which  it  will  directly  administer. 
The  Government  of  Bangladesh  will  provide  $18  million  equivalent  in  local 
currency.  
 
The  service  delivery  contract  with  NGOs  would  include  two  activities  fully 
funded  by  the  grant:  (i)  $2.5  million  for  operating  24  HIV/AIDS  voluntary 
testing  and  counseling  centers,  one  for  each  partnership  area;  and 
(ii) $5.0 million for sexually transmitted infection (STI) and reproductive tract 
infection  (RTI)  control.  Under  the  behavior  change  communication  and 
marketing  (BCCM)  component,  the  grant  will  support  $2.5  million  for 
HIV/AIDS, STI, and infectious disease control.   
 
Monitoring  and  evaluation  of  grant-funded  components  are  clearly 
distinguishable  but  have  been  integrated  into  the  design  and  monitoring 
framework.  The  monitoring  system  will  be  based  on  monthly  reports  from 
the  NGO  partners,  city  corporations,  and  municipalities  to  the  project 
management  unit  (PMU).  These  monthly  reports  will  provide  the  basis  for 
tracking  and  evaluating  specific  inputs  (e.g.,  medicines,  other  supplies, 
financial  inputs,  HIV/AIDS  control  posters  purchased)  and  outputs  (e.g., 
number of patients counseled and tested for HIV/AIDS, and patients treated 
for  RTI  and  STI).  An  independent  evaluation  firm  will  conduct  household 
surveys at project inception, midterm, and end. These will be in addition to 
surveys  of  health  facilities  to  evaluate  the  outcomes  and  impact  of  grant 
funding.  
 
For  grant  administration  purposes, 
the  Executing  Agency,  Local 
Government  Division  (LGD),  will  provide  a  separate  section  in  its  quarterly 
report to ADB covering financial and physical inputs and outputs relating to 
HIV/AIDS and other infectious disease control.  
 
The  proposed  ADB  loan  is  for  SDR  19.954  million  ($30  million  equivalent) 
from  Special  Funds  resources.  The  term  of  the  proposed  loan  will  be 
32  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years,  with  an  interest  charge  of 
1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter.

The  PMU  will  be  established  in  the  LGD  of  the  Ministry  of  Local 
Government, Rural Development and Cooperatives (MOLGRDC). A national 

 vi 

 

urban  PHC  committee  chaired  by  the  LGD  minister,  and  a  national  project 
steering  committee  chaired  by  LGD  secretary  will  be  formed  to  oversee 
policy  and  project  implementation.  Eleven  project  implementation  units  will 
be  established  in  the  six  city  corporations  and  five  municipalities  to  be 
covered.  A  city  corporation  or  municipality  PHC  committee  headed  by  the 
mayor  of  the  city  corporation  or  the  chairman  of  the  municipality  will  guide 
project implementation. At the facility level, a ward PHC committee chaired 
by  a  ward  commissioner  will  help  ensure  community  participation  and 
empower the poor to use the services provided.  
 
The  LGD  of  the  MOLGRDC  will  be  the  Executing  Agency,  and  the  city 
corporations and municipalities will be the implementing agencies. 
 
Procurement  of  ADB-financed  goods,  related  services,  and  civil  works  will 
be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Procurement  and 
local procurement may be conducted in accordance with Bangladesh Public 
Procurement Regulations (2003), acceptable to ADB. 
 
Consultants  and  consulting  firms  will  be  recruited  under  ADB’s  Guidelines 
on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for 
recruitment  of  local  consultants,  which  may  include  Bangladesh  Public 
Procurement  Regulations  (2003).  The  consulting 
firms  will  provide: 
(i) management  support  for  the  PMU  and  management  training,  (ii)  quality 
assurance  training  and  supportive  supervision,  (iii)  health  management 
information  systems  development  and  implementation,  (iv)  behavioral 
change  communication  and  marketing,  (v) financial  management  and 
performance  auditing,  (vi)  project  performance  monitoring  and  evaluation, 
and  (vii)  design  and  supervisory  engineering  services  for  construction. 
 
The  management  support  firm  will  be  responsible  for  recruiting  one  long-
term  international  consultant  (6.5  years),  one  long-term  national  consultant 
(6.5 years), two short-term international consultants for a total of 20 person-
months  (HIV/AIDS  specialist  for  12  person-months,  and  management 
information  specialist  for  8  person-months);  and  nine  short-term  national 
consultants  for  a  total  of  150  person-months  (poverty  specialist  for 
24  person-months,  institutional  development  specialist  for  24  person-
months,  gender  specialist  for  12  person-months,  environment  specialist  for 
6 person-months, resettlement specialist for 3 person-months, procurement 
specialist for 36 person-months, HIV/AIDS specialist for 24 person-months, 
nutrition  specialist  for  6  person-months,  and  management  information 
specialist for 15 person-months). 
 
Partnership agreements to deliver PHC service packages will be awarded to 
eligible  private  sector  participants  including  NGOs  in  accordance  with 
competitive  bidding  procedures  acceptable  to  ADB  and  on  similar  terms  to 
that  used  in  UPHCP-I.  The  award  of  contract  will  be  subject  to  the  bidder 
demonstrating to the satisfaction of LGD and ADB that it has the necessary 
expertise and resources to provide the PHC services.

 vii

 
The Project will improve the health status of the poor in six city corporations 
and  five  municipalities  by  providing  an  essential  package  of  high-impact 
services.  By  reducing  child  and  maternal  mortality,  the  Project  will  help 
Bangladesh achieve the MDGs for child mortality and maternal health. 
 
Women  and  children  will  constitute  more 
than  75%  of  all  project 
beneficiaries. The Project will improve the efficiency of urban health services 
by: (i) improving the spatial distribution of health centers, e.g., PHC centers, 
comprehensive  reproductive  health  care  (CRHC)  centers,  and  mini-clinics, 
in  accordance  with  population  density  and  geographical 
factors; 
(ii) supporting cost-effective interventions to reduce mortality and morbidity; 
(iii)  enabling  least-cost  private  sector  participation  in  the  provision  of 
preventive  and  promotive  health  care  services  by  partner  NGOs; 
(iv)  allowing  appropriate  user  fees;  (v)  improving  the  monitoring  and 
supervision  system;  and  (vi)  concentrating  on  provision  of  health  services 
that  will  create  the  greatest  public  good,  to  use  scarce  government 
resources more efficiently.

The  Project  will  improve  the  quality  of  PHC  by  building  the  management 
capacity  of  health  departments  in  the  six  city  corporations  and  five 
municipalities to effectively manage the health services. 
 
Health  service  improvements  in  the  project  area  will  provide  three  types  of 
economic  benefits:  (i)  health 
to  better 
productivity and learning outcomes at school; (ii) a reduction in days lost due 
to sickness or health care; and (iii) savings in out-of-pocket expenditure on 
health care because of better and more efficient health services. 
 
Delays  in  contracting-out  of  services  to  NGOs  may  jeopardize  project 
implementation.  Some  delays  may  be  due  to  challenging  procedures, 
including bid preparation, attracting effective NGOs, transparent evaluation, 
and issuing timely contracts. The proposed advance actions, combined with 
the  lessons  learned  during  UPHCP-I,  will  reduce  the  risk  of  delay.  The 
failure  to  have  a  transparent  and  competitive  bidding  process  to  select 
effective NGOs at the most competitive rates is a risk. The failure to execute 
a contract with NGOs that imposes an obligation on them to implement the 
partnership agreements effectively and, especially, target the poor is also a 
risk.  
 
The implementation risks are significant and include failure to ensure timely 
payments  to  NGOs,  and  proper  supervision  of  the  partner  NGO  to  ensure 
access 
the  poor.  UPHCP-I 
experiences have been used to design measures to reduce these potential 
risks.  The  measures 
involvement  of  city  corporations  or 
municipalities, constitution of a national PHC committee, engagement of an 
independent  project  performance  monitoring  and  evaluation  system  firm, 
provision  of  consultant  support  to  the  PMU,  careful  review  of  tender 
documents  by  ADB  and  the  Government,  and  building  on  procedures  that 
proved effective under UPHCP-I.

 viii 

 

 
Ineffective pro-poor targeting is a potential risk for the Project, and effective 
deterrents  for  not  achieving  pro-poor  targets  are  needed.  The  Project 
proposes  safeguards,  including  contractually  obligating  at  least  30%  of  the 
services to be provided free to the poor. Contracts will be designed to deter 
NGOs from failing to achieve pro-poor targets. 
 
Corruption  is  a  risk,  partly  because  the  project  implementation  is  complex. 
Hence, a number of specific measures to mitigate the risk of corruption and 
improve  governance  have  been  included  in  the  project  design.  These 
include  development  of  a  good  governance  and  anti-corruption  action  plan 
and  quarterly  reporting  of  such  action  plan,  review  through  performance 
audit  of  the  timely  disbursements  to  partner  NGOs,  strengthening  financial 
management, and beneficiary grievance resolution mechanisms.  
 
Lack  of  financial  sustainability  after  the  Project  closes  is  a  major  risk.  The 
project  benefits  are  unlikely  to  be  sustainable  after  project  completion 
without  an  appropriately  designed  fiscal  model.  The  Government  needs  to 
add at least $11.1 million to its current expenditure to sustain urban PHC in 
2012-2013 and $11.7 million per year in the following years. To mitigate this 
risk,  the  Project  will  help  the  LGD  explore  alternative  fiscal  models.  The 
Government  has  given  an  assurance  that  a  fiscal  model  will  be  selected 
within  2  years  of  loan  effectiveness  to  ensure  the  financial  sustainability  of 
the Project after its completion.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed loan 
(ii)  a  proposed  grant  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  Second  Urban  Primary 
Health  Care  Project  (the  Project),1  and  (iii)  proposed  administration  by  the  Asian  Development 
Bank (ADB) of grants for the Project to be provided by each of the Government of Sweden and 
the Government of the United Kingdom. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2.  
Bangladesh has achieved remarkable health gains in the last two decades, although it is 
still among the poorest nations in the world. Between 1990 and 2002, the under-5 mortality rate 
declined from 144 to 73 per 1,000 live births, and the infant mortality rate declined from 96 to 48 
per 1,000 live births. Bangladesh is more likely than other countries in South Asia to achieve the 
Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs)  related  to  child  health.  Life  expectancy  increased  from  
53 years in 1994 to 61 years in 2004, and the total fertility rate decreased from 6.3 in 1971 to 3.3 
in the 1990s.  
 
3.  
The  Government  of  Bangladesh  is  committed  to  improving  the  health  of  its  citizens, 
particularly the poor. Its health policy (2000) emphasizes improving the quality and efficiency of 
and access to public health services. However, most public primary health care (PHC) services 
cater to the rural population2 (Appendix 2). The Local Government Division (LGD) of the Ministry 
of Local Government, Rural Development, and Cooperatives (MOLGRDC)  implemented the first 
Urban  Primary  Health  Care  Project  (UPHCP-I)  in  four  city  corporations—Dhaka,  Chittagong, 
Kulna,  and  Rajshahi.  UPHCP-I,  which  supported  the  contracting-out  of  PHC  services  to 
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  through  partnership  agreements,  will  come  to  a  close  at 
the end of June 2005. At the request of the Government, ADB approved technical assistance3 to 
prepare  the  Project,  which  aims  to  consolidate  the  gains  of  UPHCP-I  and  expand  urban  PHC 
services  to  the  remaining  two  city  corporations—Sylhet  and  Barisal—and  five  municipalities—
Bogra, Comilla, Sirajgonj, Madhabdi, and Savar.  
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Key Problems 

Urban  Population  Growth  and  Poverty.  The  urban  population—currently  31  million— 
4. 
is  increasing  rapidly.  The  urban  poor  increased  from  7  million  in  1985  to  12  million  in  1999. 
Although  hardcore  poverty  (less  than  1,805  kilocalories  per  day  per  head)  decreased  by  
1.36  million  households    between  1991  (4.83  million)  and  2000  (3.47  million)  in  rural  areas,  it 
increased by 0.53 million in urban areas (from 0.65 million in 1991 to 1.18 million in 2000).4 The 
health indicators are worse for the urban poor than for the rural poor.5  
 

                                                 
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  Primary health care (PHC) services provided by municipalities represent 0.34% by value of all health services, and 

only 7% by value of the government services delivered by rural health facilities.

5. 
Health Inequities. The health inequities are wide and disturbing. For example, the poor-
to-rich  ratio  of  child  mortality  is  1.6–1.9:1.0  (child  mortality  is  60–90%  higher  in  the  poorest 
quintile than in the richest quintile). The poor-to-rich ratio for child malnutrition is even worse: 2:1 
for  moderate  stunting  and  underweight  (moderate)  and  5:1  for  severe  underweight.  Gender 
inequalities  are  persistent:  mortality  in  male  children  aged  1–4  years  is  28  per  1,000  live  births 
compared with 38 per 1,000 live births in girls in the same age group.  
 
6. 
Fertility  Decline  and  Population  Growth.  Despite  good  progress  made  in  the  last  two 
decades, the total fertility rate stalled at around 3 from 1995 to 2003. Bangladesh must achieve a 
replacement fertility rate quickly. Among other measures, contraceptive prevalence needs to be 
raised to 70–75% from the current 54% if the population is to stabilize.  
 
7. 
Reproductive and Child Health. The current maternal mortality ratio is 300 per 100,000 
live births. Bangladesh has low rates of antenatal care6 and only 6% of deliveries take place in 
health facilities. Assistance by skilled birth attendants at the residence of pregnant women will be 
key  to  further  reducing  maternal  mortality.  Only  48%  of  the  children  who  reported  acute 
respiratory  infections  and  36%  of  children  with  diarrhea  were  taken  to  a  health  facility  for 
treatment.  Of  the  children  with  diarrhea,  20%  were  not  given  oral  rehydration  solution,  
or recommended home-made fluid or increased fluid intake.  
 
Malnutrition. High rates of malnutrition persist despite progress made in the last decade, 
8. 
remain.  Almost  half  of  women  and  78%  of  children  
and  micronutrient  deficiencies 
6–11 months of age suffer from anemia; 45% of all children under 5 years are considered short 
for their age or stunted, and 18% of all children are severely stunted. Of children under 5, 48% of 
children  are  underweight  and  13%,  severely  underweight.  Maternal  malnutrition  is  high:  6%  of 
pregnant women are severely malnourished and 12%, moderately malnourished. 
 
HIV/AIDS  and  Other  Infectious  Diseases.  Although  HIV/AIDS7  prevalence  rates  are 
9. 
low,8 HIV/AIDS prevention and counseling services must be expanded in urban areas to control 
further  spread  of  the  virus.  Knowledge  about  HIV/AIDS  in  urban  areas  is  still  only  64%  among 
women who have ever been married. While 83% of urban women had no knowledge of sexually 
transmitted  infections  (STIs),  73%  of  urban  men  had  no  knowledge.9  The  emergence  of  drug-
resistant  malaria  and  tuberculosis  (TB)  is  a  major  concern.  The  total  prevalence  rate  of  smear-
positive cases of TB is 910 per 100,000 population, 1,190 in the male population, and 540 in the 
female population.10 TB case detection rates, estimated as low as 34%, need to be increased to 
at  least  75%,  and  cure  rates  need  to  be  sustained  at  85%,  which  will  require  concerted  and 
additional efforts among the urban poor.  
 
10. 
Resource  Gap.  Bangladesh’s  per  capita  health  expenditures—public  and  private— 
are low. Of the total $11 per capita expenditure on health in 1997, only $3 was contributed by the 
public  sector,  which  is  far  below  the  World  Health  Organization  (WHO)  Commission  on 
Macroeconomics and Health’s estimated minimum financial needs of $30–40 per person per year 
to  cover  only  essential  health  interventions.11  The  situation  is  much  worse  for  urban  areas,  as 
most public subsidies for PHC target rural areas (Appendix 2).

leaves more than 2.5 million pregnancies annually without any antenatal care.

2. 

Opportunities and Lessons Learned 

increasing 

Opportunities.  Although 

the  urban  population  has  been 

11. 
rapidly,  
the Government and external funding agencies have addressed urban PHC seriously only in the 
last  decade.  The  ADB-supported  UPHCP-I  and  United  States  Agency  for  International 
Development (USAID)-supported NGO service delivery program, which contract out urban PHC 
to  NGOs  (Supplementary  Appendix  A),  are  the  only  major  urban  PHC  projects  in  Bangladesh, 
leaving  significant  needs  for  urban  PHC  unmet.  Bangladesh’s  health  policy  adopted  in  2000 
stresses the need to expand health services in urban areas, especially for the poor. The interim 
poverty reduction strategy paper12 and the targets set in the Partnership Agreement on Poverty 
Reduction  (PAPR)  with  ADB  reflect  the  Government’s  commitment  to  achieving  the  MDGs  by 
strengthening urban PHC, especially for the poor. 
 
ADB’s country strategy supports delivery of PHC services in urban areas over the medium 
12. 
term,  and  building  local  government  capacity  to  deliver  high-quality  services  to  the  urban  poor, 
particularly  women  and  children,  in  partnership  with  NGOs.13  The  country  assistance  program 
evaluation  (CAPE)  in  2003  highlighted  the  need  for  stronger  collaboration  with  NGOs,  more 
effective empowerment of local communities, and support for accountable and transparent local 
government  bodies  in  ADB’s  future  programs.14  The  Project  is  therefore  closely  aligned  with: 
ADB’s  overall  policy  for  reducing  human  poverty  and  helping  developing  member  countries 
achieve  the  MDGs;  Bangladesh’s  national  poverty  reduction  strategy;  the  PAPR;  the  country 
strategy and program update; and the recommendations of the 2003 CAPE. 
 
Lessons  Learned.  The  lessons  learned  from  reviews15  of  UPHCP-I,  especially  those 
13. 
relating  to  better  pro-poor  targeting,  adequate  provision  of  medicines,  support  for  quality 
assurance,  greater  emphasis  on  behavior  change  communication,  the  need  for  environmental 
health  improvement,  and  institutional  mechanisms  for  greater  involvement  by  city  mayors  have 
been  incorporated  into  the  Project’s  design  (Appendix  3).  The  strengths  of  UPHCP-I— 
the  partnership  agreements  that  harness  private  sector/NGO  provision  of  a  public  service,  for 
example—have been retained in the Project. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

14. 
The Project will improve the health status of the urban population, especially of the poor, 
in  six  city  corporations—Dhaka,  Chittagong,  Khulna,  Rajshahi,  Sylhet  and  Barisal—and  five 
municipalities—Bogra,  Comilla,  Sirajgonj,  Madhabdi,  and  Savar.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. At least 30% of all the project services will target the poor (Appendix 
4).  The  specific  project  objectives  are:  (i)  to  improve  equitable  access  and  use  of  urban  PHC 
services  in  the  project  area,  with  a  focus  on  providing  them  to  the  poorest;  (ii)  to  improve  the 
quality of urban PHC services in the project area; and (iii) to improve the cost-effectiveness and 
efficiency and the institutional and financial sustainability of PHC to serve the urban poor.

Outputs

The  Project  has  the  following  four  components,  which  were  designed  through  intensive

1. 

Provision  of  Primary  Health  Care  through  Partnership  Agreements  and 
Behavior Change Communication and Marketing 

a. 

Partnership Agreements  

to  provide  PHC  services 

The  Project  will  continue

through  performance-based 
contracting-out  of  PHC  services  to  NGOs.  It  will  use  partnership  agreements  similar  to  those 
pioneered  during  UPHCP-I.  The  partner  NGOs  will  provide  essential  services  package  plus 
(ESP+)  services  (Supplementary  Appendix  B)  in  the  partnership  agreement  areas.  These 
services  will  consist  of  (i)  a  HIV/AIDS  voluntary  counseling  and  testing  (VCT)  center  for  each 
partnership  area;  (ii)  STI  and  reproductive  tract  infection  (RTI)  control;  and  (iii)  other  essential 
services package (ESP) plus. Subcomponents (i) and (ii) will be financed by the ADB grant and 
subcomponent (iii) by other financing. 
 
17. 
A procedure acceptable to ADB will be followed when selecting partner NGOs (Appendix 
5).  A  national  bid  evaluation  committee  will  evaluate  the  technical  and  financial  bids.  
The  committee  will  be  chaired  by  the  LGD  secretary  and  will  include  a  representative  from  the 
Ministry  of  Health  and  Family  Welfare  (MOHFW)  (at  not  less  than  deputy  secretary  level), 
representatives  of  cofinancers  (including  the  United  Nations  Population  Fund  (UNFPA)),  and 
representatives of United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) and WHO.  
 
 18. 
The  Project  will  finance  24  partnership  agreements,  each  covering  200,000–300,000 
people. Each partnership agreement area will consist of one comprehensive reproductive health 
care  (CRHC)  center,  at  least  one  PHC  center  per  30,000–50,000  people,  and  at  least  one 
satellite  or  mini-clinic  per  10,000  people.  PHC  centers  will  provide  a  full  range  of  essential 
services, 
including  basic  emergency  obstetric  care.  The  CRHC  centers  will  provide 
comprehensive emergency obstetric care, newborn care, and specialized ESP+ services. Two of 
the  three  partnership  areas  in  Chittagong  will  be  covered  by  the  city  corporation  health 
department, while the remaining area will be contracted out to a partner NGO, as for UPHCP-I. 
UNFPA will continue to support strengthening of CRHC centers by providing equipment, supplies, 
and training through parallel cofinancing. The Project will support CRHC-center-based HIV/AIDS 
voluntary testing and counseling services for HIV/AIDS through grant financing.  
 
19. 
The partnership agreements will ensure that at least 30% of each service will be provided 
free to the poor, who will be identified through participatory poverty assessments and household 
listings  conducted  by  the  partner  NGO  (Appendix  4).  Pro-poor  targeting  will  be  an  important 
aspect of the performance-based contracting. The poor will be provided free services, including 
free  medicines.  A  performance  bonus  will  be  paid  to  the  partner  NGOs  for  their  demonstrated 
ability 
(Appendix  5).  
In  addition,  utilization,  equity,  cost-efficiency,  quality,  and  health  impact  will  help  determine  the 
performance  bonus.  For  the  nonpoor,  sliding  user  fees  will  be  charged  and  drugs  will  be  made 
available at 10–20% lower than market price.

b. 

Behavior Change Communication and Marketing16 

The  main  elements  of  the  behavior  change  communication  and  marketing  (BCCM) 
21. 
strategy for the Project will be as follows: (i) branding of project service networks; (ii) innovative 
marketing to maximize use of the Project, targeting providers and potential clients and patients; 
(iii)  community  mobilization  through  national  campaigns  and  direct  interventions  by  partner 
NGOs;  (iv)  raising  awareness  of  communicable  and  noncommunicable  disease  control;  and  
(v)  increasing  knowledge  and  awareness  of  HIV/AIDS  and  STI  prevention  and  control.  These 
components will focus on raising awareness among the poor of their rights to health care and the 
particular health needs of women  and girls, and ensuring they know  free services are available 
for the poor. The two subcomponents of BCCM will be (i) HIV/AIDS, STI and infectious disease 
control,  and  (ii)  other  ESP-related  behavior  change.  Subcomponents  (i)  will  be  financed  by  the 
ADB grant, and subcomponent (ii) by other financing. BCCM will be contracted out to a firm or an 
institution, which will work closely with the  project management unit (PMU), partner NGOs, and 
the  city  corporations  and  municipalities  to  prepare  a  BCCM  strategy  with  short-  and  long-term 
implementation plans that will be approved by the LGD and ADB.

Urban Primary Health Care Infrastructure and Environmental Health 

a. 

Urban Primary Health Care infrastructure 

22. 
The Project will construct 50 PHC and 14 CRHC centers, and upgrade 4 PHC centers to 
CRHC  centers.  The  Project  will  support  the  purchase  of  12  apartments  or  buildings  for  PHC 
centers in Dhaka (Table 1).17 Construction will be completed within 3 years of loan effectiveness. 
Under the overall guidance of the PMU, the city corporations and municipalities will implement the 
civil  works.  A  design  and  construction  supervision  firm  will  be  hired  to  support  the  PMU.  Land 
acquisition  will  be  minimal  as  most  of  the  land  will  be  either  government-owned  or  donated.  
The PHC and CRHC centers will operate in rented buildings until the new facilities are available.

charge  nominal  user  fees.  The  partner  NGOs  will  mobilize  local  communities  and  ensure  that

budget. The approach will be evaluated to ensure that it is sustainable and to ensure appropriate

D. 

Special Features 

32. 
 In South Asia, provision of PHC is ordinarily characterized by three features. First, PHC 
services are mainly provided in rural areas. Second, the Ministry of Health is usually the ministry 
primary responsible for service provision. Third, PHC is mainly funded and provided as a public 
service by the government. The project features a design that uniquely contrasts with these three 
aspects. First, like UPHCP-I, the project will cater to Bangladesh’s growing urban population, and 
would  expand  to  new  urban  areas.  Second,  LGD  in  the  MOLGRDC  is  the  project’s  executing 
agency.  This  is  designed  to  ensure  decentralized  PHC  service  provision  through  greater 
involvement  of  city  corporations  and  municipalities.    With  such  decentralized  provision  of  public 
services,  the  potential  exists  for  increased  accountability  of  providers  and  local  governments  to 
beneficiaries  and  end-users.    Third,  the  project  design  envisages  provision  of  PHC  services  by 
private  providers  through  partnership  agreements—contracting-out  principally  to  NGOs.    While 
this special feature facilitates “private provision of a public services”, the design of the partnership 
agreements  is  performance-based  with  incentives  and  contractual  stipulations  that  enhance 
quality.    Additionally,  the  agreements  include  a  contractual  obligation  to  provide  30%  of  the 
services to the poor. Specific criteria have been developed so that NGOs can identify who are the 
“urban  poor”  and  to  ensure  standardization  of  service  provision  amongst  the  different  NGO 
providers.    To  prevent  false  claims  for  services  once  identified,  the  urban  poor  will  be  provided 
entitlement cards, by which the poor will be able to access free PHC services from partners.   The 
project  displays  a  specific  emphasis  on  refinements  that  will  ensure  smooth  and  effective 
implementation. 
 
Because  of  the  project’s  complexity,  the  additional  risk  of  corruption  in  Bangladesh  has 
33. 
been recognized and will be addressed by a number of project specific design measures. These 
include assigning important roles in project implementation and monitoring to the private sector, 
local  governments,  community-based  organizations,  and  beneficiaries;  focusing  on  improving 
management information systems and financial management; and strengthening information flow 
to stakeholders through outreach service. As well as these measures the government will engage 
an  independent  firm  for  project  performance  monitoring  and  evaluation  and  an  independent 
performance  auditor  to  review,  among  other  things,  timely  disbursement  to  NGOs.  It  will  also 
establish a beneficiary grievance redress mechanism; and develop a good governance and anti-
corruption action plan. The government will report on the implementation of the action plan each 
quarter.  In  addition,  as  a  result  of  the  success  of  UPHCP-I,  and  ADB’s  active  coordination  with 
other development partners, ADB has catalyzed the provision of additional resources from three 
development  partners.  Significant  grant  cofinance  from  the  Government  of  Sweden,  the 
Government  of  the  United  Kingdom  and  UNFPA  highlight  the  wider  acceptance  of  the  project

model  for  provision  of  urban  PHC  in  Bangladesh.  The  benefits  of  this  cofinance  act  not  only  to

G. 

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Project Management 

37. 
The  LGD  of  MOLGRDC  will  be  the  Executing  Agency.  The  city  corporations  and  the 
municipalities  will  be  the  implementing  agencies  in  their  project  areas.  The  organizational  chart 
indicating  the  project  management  and  implementation  structure  is  set  forth  in  Appendix  8  and 
Supplementary  Appendix  E.  A  national  urban  primary  health  care  committee  (NUPHCC)  will  be 
chaired  by  the  LGD  minister.  The  committee  will  include  members  from  ministries  such  as 
MOHFW and mayors and chairmen of city corporations and municipalities covered by the Project. 
The NUPHCC will meet at least twice a year and guide urban PHC, ensure greater involvement in 
and ownership of the Project by mayors of city corporations and chairmen of municipalities, and 
forge stronger links with relevant ministries. For project implementation, the apex body will be the 
national project steering committee (NPSC), chaired by the LGD secretary, which will guide the 
PMU. The NPSC will meet at least four times a year during the first 2 years of operations, and at 
least twice every year thereafter.  

38. 
The chief project coordinator will be a joint secretary-level officer of LGD or higher. He or 
she will supervise a full-time project director, who will be acceptable to ADB and will be selected 
from senior civil servants. The project director will be at least a deputy-secretary-level officer and 
have project management experience, preferably in the health sector. The deputy project director, 
administration  and  finance,21  will  be  at  least  at  the  level  of  senior  assistant  secretary  officer  of 
LGD. The deputy project director, technical, will be a medical doctor with a postgraduate degree 
or diploma and be a member of staff of LGD or city corporation health department with more than 
5 years’ experience in a similar project.  

                                                 
21 Based on a review of financial management capacity and previous experience, the project management unit (PMU) 
has been strengthened in financial management by engaging a senior civil servant as deputy director, administration 
and finance, and a financial management and performance audit firm. 

 

  

11  

39. 
The  city  corporation  or  municipality  PHC  coordination  committees  will  be  chaired  by  the 
mayor  or  chairman  or,  in  their  absence,  the  chief  executive  officer.  Before  loan  effectiveness, 
PIUs  will  be  constituted  in  Dhaka,  Chittagong,  Kulna,  and  Rajshahi.  A  ward  PHC  coordination 
committee  will  be  chaired  by  local  ward  commissioners  and  co-chaired  by  zonal  health  officers 
(where  available)  and  female  ward  commissioners,  with  a  membership  that  represents  all  local 
stakeholders, including informal settlers.  
 

2. 

Implementation Schedule 

The Project will be implemented over 6.5 years, from July 2005 to December 2011. During 
40. 
the  first  6  months,  the  bidding  process  for  24  partnership  agreements  will  be  completed.  PHC 
services will be provided through new partnership agreements from January 2006 in the existing 
four city corporations and from July 2006 in the two new city corporations and five municipalities.  
The Project’s long duration is justified for the following reasons: (i) short contracts lead to frequent 
changes  in  providers,  which  might  not  be  in  the  clients’  best  interests;  (ii)  rebidding  and 
mobilization  of  new  partner  NGOs  will  involve  management  costs  and  a  risk  of  disruption  of 
service  provision;  and  (iii)  uncertainties  caused  by  short  contracts  may  dissuade  the  partner 
NGOs from proper investments and they may therefore compromise on quality. The disadvantage 
of  a  longer  contract  is  the  risk  of  being  stuck  with  nonperforming  partner  NGOs.  Adequate 
provisions will be made to discourage poor performance and to revoke contracts when a partner 
NGO  falls  below  set  standards  or  is  in  breach  of  contract  terms  and  conditions.  An 
implementation schedule is in Appendix 9. 
 

 

3. 

Procurement of Goods and Services 

a. 

Civil Works 

41. 
Civil works subprojects (consisting of the construction of 14 CRHC and 50 PHC centers, 
the purchase of 12 apartments, and the upgrading of four PHC centers to CRHC centers) will be 
small ($100,000 to $500,000), and scattered over six city corporations and five municipalities, and 
unlikely to attract foreign bidders. The subprojects will therefore be awarded by local competitive 
bidding procedures as described in the Government’s Public Procurement Regulations 2003, and 
acceptable  to  ADB.  Funds  to  purchase  apartments  and/or  land  will  be  from  the  Government’s 
contribution only. Civil works contracts below $100,000 will be permitted only case by case. The 
Government will submit, through the PMU, details of the number and scope of civil works for ADB 
approval  before  withdrawing  funds  for  civil  works  expenditure.  Construction  contracts  will  be 
required  to  contain  stated  compliance  with  labor  law  requirements,  and  to  bind  contractors  to 
comply  with  applicable  labor  legislation,  including  that  on  child  labor.  In  Dhaka,  where  suitable 
land for further PHC centers will be difficult to obtain, LGD may consider and approve any request 
from the PMU to purchase a flat in a new apartment or building. It is expected that the design of 
these  new  flats  or  buildings  can  be  modified  to  meet  requirements  for  PHC  or  CRHC  center 
operations.  

b. 

Equipment and Materials 

42. 
Vehicles,  computers,  equipment  (Supplementary  Appendix  F),  and  accessories  will  be 
procured  through  international  competitive  bidding  for  packages  above  $500,000  and  by 
international  shopping  for  packages  below  $500,000,  financed  from  ADB  loan  and  cofinance 
grant  funds  administered  by  ADB,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Procurement.  LCB 
procedures  may  also  be  used  for  packages  below  $500,000,  financed  from  ADB  loan  and 
cofinance grant funds administered by ADB, in accordance with Public Procurement Regulations 
2003, and acceptable to ADB. Packages less than equivalent of $50,000 but more than $10,000 

 

 

 12 

 

may be awarded by National Shopping procedures acceptable to ADB; and packages equivalent 
of $10,000 or less may be awarded by direct purchase procedures acceptable to ADB. To ensure 
economy and efficiency, goods of similar nature will be grouped into packages under one or more 
bids. Apart from supplies directly provided from MOHFW and UNFPA, the partner NGOs will be 
responsible for the purchase of all furniture, equipment, medicines, and other supplies necessary 
to meet the terms of their partnership agreements.  
 

c. 

Consulting Services 

The LGD will recruit consultants and consulting firms as per ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
43. 
of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  recruitment  of  local  consultants, 
which may include the Public Procurement Regulations, 2003. Consulting firms will be hired using 
quality- and cost-based selection. They will include: (i) a management and training support firm; 
(ii)  a  quality  assurance  training  and  supportive  supervision  firm,  (iii)  a  HMIS  development  and 
implementation firm, (iv) a behavioral change communication and marketing firm, (v) a financial 
management and performance audit firm,22 (vi) a project performance monitoring and evaluation 
firm, and (vii) the design and supervisory engineering services of a construction firm (Appendix 10 
and Supplementary Appendix C). The Management Support Firm, among others, will provide the 
services  of  the  following  experts:  one  long-term  international  consultant  for  78  person-months; 
one long-term national consultant for 78 person-months; two short-term international consultants 
for a total of 20 person-months (HIV/AIDS specialist for 12 person-months, and HMIS specialist 
for 8 person-months); and nine short-term national consultants for a total of 150 person-months 
(poverty  specialist  for  24  person-months,  institutional  development  specialist  for  24  person-
months,  gender  specialist  for  12  person-months,  environment  specialist  for  6  person-months, 
resettlement  specialist  for  3  person-months,  procurement  specialist  for  36  person-months, 
HIV/AIDS  specialist  for  24  person-months,  nutrition  specialist  for  6  person-months,  and 
management information specialist for 15 person-months). The detailed terms of reference for the 
firms,  including  qualification  and  deployment  schedule  of  consultants  to  be  hired  through  the 
management  firm,  are  in  Supplementary  Appendix  C.  At  midterm  appraisal,  the  needs  for 
additional consultant support will be assessed.

Partnership Agreements 

Partnership  agreements  to  deliver  the  PHC  service  package  will  be  awarded  in 
44.

PHC services in UPHCP-I or similar programs, and additional weight will be given to NGOs that 
provide similar services in the specific partnership area.

Disbursement Arrangements

8. 

Project Review 

50. 
The Government, ADB, and other cofinancers will jointly review the Project’s progress at 
least twice a year. The representatives of the health consortium with an interest in urban PHC will 
be  invited  to  join  the  reviews.  Efforts  will  be  made  to  ensure  the  project  review  coincides  with 
MOHFW’s  health,  nutrition,  and  population  sector  program  review.  The  Government,  ADB,  and 
other cofinancers will jointly review the Project in the middle of its third year. This midterm review 
will:  (i)  examine  the  scope,  design,  implementation  arrangements,  and  other  relevant  issues  in 
light of the Government’s development strategies and the policy framework; (ii) examine progress 
in  achieving  the  Project’s  measurable  objectives,  with  emphasis  on  catering  to  the  urban  poor, 
especially women and girls; (iii) identify changes since appraisal in issues related to urban PHC 
future  project 
and  resource  management  and  allocation,  and  assess 
implementation  and  sustainability;  (iv)  assess  implementation  performance  against  appropriate 
projections;  (v)  review  and  establish  compliance  with  various  loan  covenants;  (vi)  identify 
problems  and  constraints;  and  (vii)  recommend  corrective  action.  The  midterm  review  will 
evaluate  the  use  and  projected  use  of  funds,  and,  if  necessary,  expand  the  Project  to  new 
municipalities, or deepen services within existing project areas, depending on projected savings.

involvement will depend on LGD achieving predetermined benchmarks of performance, including 
timely  contracting-out  of  PHC  services  to  NGOs,  sound  implementation,  targeting  the  poor 
(especially women and girls), and achieving good governance. Further ADB and external funding 
agencies support to urban PHC delivery will depend on LGD’s performance.

9. 

Project Performance Monitoring and Evaluation 

52. 
The  LGD  and  PMU  will  establish  a  comprehensive  project  performance  monitoring  and 
evaluation  system  (PPMES)  acceptable  to  ADB  and  other  cofinancers.  The  PPMES  will:  (i) 
assess  technical  performance;  (ii)  evaluate  delivery  of  planned  activities;  (iii)  measure  project 
impacts;  (iv)  measure  social  and  economic  benefits  with  a  focus  on  the  poor,  women,  and 
adolescents; and (v) monitor achievements of health-related MDGs. PPMES indicators will serve 
as  a  basis  for  reports  on  project  implementation,  and  will  cover  fiscal  impact,  improved  use  of 
resources, changes in access to services (particularly among the poor), improved service quality, 
cost  savings  from  rationalization,  client  satisfaction,  and  MDG  progress  status.  Baseline  values 
for  these  indicators  will  be  estimated  from  participatory  assessments  and  from  household  and 
health  facility  surveys.  The  midterm  and  final  values  of  the  indicators  will  be  estimated  from 
similar participatory assessments and from household and health facility surveys. The indicators 
will  be  disaggregated  by  socioeconomic  status  and  gender  of  the  beneficiaries  to  assess  the 
impact  in  reducing  inequities.  A  PPMES  firm  will  be  engaged  to  conduct  participatory 
assessments  and  household  and  health  facility  surveys.  A  quality  assurance  firm  will  be 
responsible  for  monitoring  and  assessing  the  technical  performance  of  the  partner  NGOs 
(Supplementary Appendix C).

A. 

Project Benefits 

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

Improved Health Status. The Project will improve the health status of people living in the 
53. 
six  city  corporations  and  five  municipal  towns  by  providing  an  essential  package  of  high-impact 
services. By reducing child and maternal mortality, the Project will help Bangladesh achieve the 
health-related MDGs. 
 
54. 
Improved  Equity  and  Efficiency  in  the  Health  Sector.  The  Project  will  improve  the 
efficiency of urban health care services by: (i) improving the spatial distribution of health centers, 
e.g.,  PHC  and  CRHC  centers,  and  mini-clinics,  in  accordance  with  population  density  and 
geographical factors; (ii) supporting cost-effective interventions to reduce mortality and morbidity; 
(iii)  enabling  least-cost  private  sector  participation  in  the  provision  of  preventive  and  promotive 
health  care  services  through  partnership  agreements;  (iv)  allowing  appropriate  user  fees;  
(v)  improving  the  monitoring  and  supervision  system;  and  (vi)  concentrating  on  the  provision  of 
health  services  that  will  produce  the  greatest  public  good  to  use  scarce  government  resources 
more efficiently. Women and children will constitute more than 75% of all project beneficiaries.24 

55. 
Improved  Management  Capacity.  The  Project  will  build  the  management  capacity  of 
health  departments  in  the  six  city  corporations  and  five  municipalities  so  they  can  effectively 
deliver  urban  PHC  services  by:  (i)  providing  training  in  different  management  techniques;  
(ii)  developing  tools  so  the  urban  health  system  can  be  supervised  effectively,  including  HMIS; 
and  (iii)  building  capacity  of  health  departments  of  the  city  corporations  and  municipalities  for 
financial management and analysis so cost-efficiencies can be achieved. 

56. 
Economic  Gains.  The  Project  will  provide  three  types  of  economic  benefits:  (i)  health 
improvements that lead to better productivity and learning outcomes at school, (ii) a reduction in 
days lost due to sickness or health care, and (iii) savings in out-of-pocket expenditures on health 
care because of better and more efficient health services (Appendix 11). 
 
B. 

Risks 

57. 
Delays  in  Implementation.  UPHCP-I  was  delayed  by  2  years  for  various  reasons 
(Appendix 3). Delays in contracting-out of services to NGOs may also jeopardize implementation 
of this Project. The Project could be held up by challenging procedures, including bid preparation, 
attracting  effective  NGOs,  the  need  for  transparent  evaluation,  and  issuing  contracts.  However, 
these  risks  should  be  reduced  because  the  PIU  of  UPHCP-I  is  fully  functional  and  can  help 
contract partner NGOs in advance, procedures that were tested during UPHCP-I will help reduce 
the preparation time for contracting, and coordination between MOHFW and LGD is better than 
during the early stages of UPHCP-I. 
 
58. 
Risks  in  Partnership  Agreements.  Partnership  agreements  have  both  procedural  and 
implementation  risks.  Procedural  risks  include  the  possibility  that  the  bidding  process  to  select 
effective NGOs at the most competitive rates will not be transparent and that a contract obligating 
NGOs  to  implement  the  partnership  agreement,  and  especially  to  target  the  poor,  will  not  be 
executed.  The  implementation  risks  are  significant:  NGOs  may  not  be  paid  on  time  or  properly 
supervised  to  ensure  they  guarantee  access  to  high-quality  services,  especially  for  the  poor. 

                                                 
24 Ninety percent of project  services will be based on the essential service package (ESP). ESP’s predominant focus is 
maternal and child health. Under UPHCP-I, more than 75% of the beneficiaries were women and children, and more 
than 50% female. 

 

 16 

 

Corruption  and  Governance.  Corruption 

Involvement of city corporations and municipalities will improve local participation in the Project, 
but  may  also  mean  increased  local  pressure  on  NGOs  and  the  Project.  Lessons  learned  in 
UPHCP-I that may help reduce these potential risks include the following: city corporations and 
municipalities should be involved in the Project, a national PHC committee should be constituted, 
an  independent  PPMES  firm  should  be  engaged,  consultant  support  should  be  provided  to  the 
PMU,  tender  documents  should  be  reviewed  carefully  by  ADB  and  the  Government,  and  the 
Project should build on procedures that were successful under UPHCP-I. 
 
59.  Weak  Pro-Poor  Targeting.  For  a  variety  of  reasons  related  to  project  design,  pro-poor 
targeting in UPHCP-I was not optimal (Appendix 3). This could be a risk for the Project. Without 
adequate  disincentives,  partner  NGOs  may  not  target  the  poor  enough.  Safeguards  are 
proposed, including contractually obligating NGOs to provide at least 30% of their services to the 
poor.  The  bidding  process  will  ensure  adequate  medicines  are  provided  and  that  these  will  be 
free  to  the  poor.  Disincentives  for  noncompliance,  including  termination  of  the  contract,  will  be 
built into the contracts. 
 
60. 
the  project 
implementation  is  complex.  However,  measures  to  reduce  the  risk  of  corruption  and  improve 
governance have been included in the project design. These include: (i) assigning important roles 
in  project  implementation  and  monitoring  to  the  private  sector,  local  governments,  community-
based  organizations,  and  beneficiaries;  (ii)  improving  management  information  systems  and 
financial  management,  including  by  requiring  financial  audits  to  be  provided  within  6  months  of 
financial year end; (iii) enhancing the free flow of information to all stakeholders; (iv) performance-
based  contracting,  including  incentives  (a  performance  bonus)  for  demonstrated  performance 
ability; (v) engaging an independent PPMES firm and instituting a beneficiary grievance redress 
mechanism; (vi) review through performance audit of the timely disbursements to partner NGOs; 
and  (vii)  development  of  a  good  governance  and  anti-corruption  action  plan  and  quarterly 
reporting on the action plan. 
 
Financial  Sustainability.  The  Government  needs  to  add  at  least  $11.1  million  to  its 
61. 
current annual expenditure to sustain urban PHC in 2012-2013 and $11.7 million per year more in 
subsequent  years  (Appendix  11).  The  Project’s  benefits  are  unlikely  to  be  sustainable  after 
completion  unless  an  appropriate  fiscal  model  is  in  place.  The  Project  will  help  LGD  explore 
alternative models, and the Government has given an assurance that one will be selected within 
two years of loan effectiveness to ensure the Project is financially sustainable after its completion.

is  a  risk,  partly  because 

Environmental Issues  

62. 
This  is  a  category-B  project.  An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  (Supplementary 
Appendix G) was undertaken, and the summary IEE is in Appendix 12. The IEE shows that the 
Project’s environmental benefits will be substantial, resulting from improved environmental health 
through the expansion of PHC, particularly to the poor. It also shows that the potential adverse 
impacts  are  not  significant,  localized,  and  can  be  mitigated.  As  the  location  and  design  of  the 
PHC  and  CRHC  centers  will  take  place  during  project  implementation,  an  environmental 
assessment  and  review  framework  (Supplementary  Appendix  H)  will  be  developed  to  guide 
environmental  screening  and  assessment  and  to  facilitate  compliance  with  the  environmental 
requirements of the Government and ADB. 
 
D. 

Land Acquisition and Resettlement 

63. 
Construction of health facilities and community latrines will require only 3 hectares. Most 
construction  will  occur  on  either  government  land  or  voluntarily  donated  land,  arranged  by  the 

 

  

17  

government.  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary  resettlement  will  be  followed.  The  PMU  will  use  the 
resettlement framework in Appendix 13 to prepare a resettlement plan, which will be submitted to 
ADB  for  approval.  A  short  resettlement  plan  prepared  for  the  six  city  corporations  is  in 
Supplementary Appendix I. 
 
E. 

Social Measures 

64. 
Participation. During project preparation, discussions were held with beneficiaries, health 
staff, and officials through field studies, meetings, and workshops.  These provided information on 
health  service  availability,  health-seeking  behaviors,  and  financing  during  disease  episodes. 
During implementation the beneficiaries will provide advice on health services, health promotion 
activities,  and  access  to  the  health  services  for  the  poor.  They  will  also  be  consulted  through 
focus group discussions during project evaluation (Appendix 14). 
 
65. 
Social Assessment. More than 50% of the project population is from four main groups:  
(i)  slum  dwellers  living  legally  in  slums;  (ii)  squatters  living  illegally  on  land  owned  by  others; 
(iii) floating populations with no fixed residence; and (iv) other urban poor living throughout urban 
areas, mixed with the nonpoor. The Project will target all the four groups through mini- or satellite 
clinics, outreach activities, and domiciliary services. Both demand- and supply-side interventions 
will  be  used  to  target  the  poor.  Large  slums  will  have  mini-clinics,  which  will  be  open  in  the 
evening to maximize their use by the poor. 
 
66. 
indigenous population.  
 
67. 
Gender. More than 75% of the project beneficiaries will be women and children, as 90% 
of the services are based on the essential services package, which focuses mainly on maternal 
and child health. Women will comprise at least 50% of the Project’s health providers and at least 
30%  of  project  management  staff.  The  PPMES  will  conduct  a  gender-disaggregated  review  of 
outputs and outcomes to ensure gender equity. 
 
68. 
Poverty  Reduction.  At  least  30%  of  all  project  services  will  target  the  poor  through 
performance-based  contracting  and  behavior  change  communication  activities.  All  the  poor 
households in the partnership agreement areas will be identified, the list will be updated annually 
(Appendix 4), and entitlement cards for free health services will be issued to these households. 
PHC service use, outputs, and outcomes of the Project among poor households will be monitored 
and evaluated through a poverty-disaggregated PPMES.

User Fees Retention. Within 6 months of the effective date, the Government shall 
prepare  and  issue  a  government  order  that  shall  ensure  implementation  of  the 
following  specifications  on  user  fees:  (a)  an  objective,  transparent,  and  verifiable 
mechanism  or  formula  for  establishing  user  fees;  (b)  the  entitlement  of  each  city 
corporation, municipality, and partner NGO to retain a proportion of user fees; (c) 
the proportion of user fees that may be retained by city corporation, municipalities, 
and partner NGOs; (d) the requirement for each city corporation and municipality 
to  establish  an  urban  PHC  sustainability  fund,  and  to  deposit  the  proceeds  of  all

purposes  of  such  retained  user  fees,  which  shall  primarily  involve  targeted  PHC 
services  for  the  poor,  and  women  and  children;  and  (f)  the  condition  that  no  city 
corporation  or  municipality  may  apply  any  user  fees  deposited  in  the  urban  PHC 
sustainability  fund  for  any  purpose,  unless  such  city  corporation  or  municipality 
makes  a  financial  contribution  from  its  own  revenue  equivalent  to  the  amount  of 
user fees to be applied to such purpose.

Conditions for Loan Effectiveness 

71. 
The following will be the conditions for loan effectiveness: (i) establishment of a national 
urban primary health care committee and national project steering committee; (ii) establishment 
of a fully functional PMU and PIUs in the four  city corporations (Dhaka, Chittagong, Kulna, and 
Rajshahi);  (iii)  execution  and  delivery  of  a  project  agreement  by  each  city  corporation  and 
municipality included in the Project; and (iv) approval by the Government of the project pro forma 
for carrying out the Project.

SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS: URBAN PRIMARY HEALTH CARE IN BANGLADESH 

 

Introduction  

A. 
 
1. 
Urban Areas. Urban Bangladesh can be divided into four broad categories. In the first 
category are the two largest city corporations—Dhaka and Chittagong—with more than 1 million 
people. The remaining four city corporations—Khulna, Rajshahi, Sylhet, and Barisal—and large 
municipalities  (mostly  old  district  headquarters)  are  in  the  second  category,  with  an  average 
population  of  100,000.  The  third  category  contains  municipalities  with a population  of  35,000–
80,000.  Included  in  the  fourth  category  are  small  municipalities  (fewer  than  35,000  people). 
Some urban areas in the fourth category have Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW) 
health and family welfare centers.

Dhaka’s population is expected to be 22 million, which will make it the fourth largest city in the world, next only 
to Tokyo, Mumbai, and Lagos.

Growing  Urban  Population.  According  to  the  2001  census,  Bangladesh  has  a 
2. 
population  of  132  million,  of  which  approximately  23%  (or  31  million)  live  in  urban  areas, 
including six city corporations and 282 municipalities. The urban population is increasing by 6% 
per  annum  from  rural  to  urban  migration  and  because  subdistrict  headquarters  are  being 
declared  municipalities.  By  2010,  the  urban  population  is  expected  to  be  a  third  of  the  total 
population  and  is  set  to  rise  to  50  million  by  2030,  and  by  2015  Dhaka  is  expected  to  be  the 
fourth  largest  city  in  the  world  (Figure  A2).  About  25%  of  the  urban  population  is  very  poor 
(consuming fewer than 1,805 kilocalories per day) and lives mostly in slums and squatter areas. 
Of the urban poor in Dhaka, 48% live in slums while the rest live on the streets or at their work 
sites. Studies reveal that 20% of Dhaka’s population lives in slums.

Type of Health Service Providers  

Urban Health and Vulnerable Population 

 
B. 
 
3. 
Health Status. Child morbidity and mortality are highest in urban slums mainly because 
of  poor  sanitation  and  nutrition,  which  decrease  immunity  and  resistance;  crowding,  which 
facilitates disease transmission; poverty, which prevents or delays treatment; lack of affordable 
primary health care (PHC); and lack of a social safety network.  
 
Vulnerable  Urban  Populations.  The  different  types  of  vulnerable  urban  populations 
4. 
include  people  living  in  slums;  households  headed  by  females;  floating  and  homeless  people; 
street  children;  victims  of  violence;  commercial  sex  workers;  men  who  have  sex  with  men; 
transgender  people;  rickshaw  pullers;  truck  drivers;  and  industry  workers  (such  as  female 
garment factory workers, port workers, etc.). 
 
C. 
 
Nongovernment  Organizations  (NGOs).  Contracted  NGOs  financially  supported  by 
5. 
the  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  (USAID)  and  the  Asian  Development 
Bank  (ADB)  have  been  the  chief  providers  of  publicly  financed  PHC  service  delivery  in  urban 
Bangladesh since 1997.  
 
6. 
Public Sector. The municipalities and city corporations have a few health facilities and 
clinics, mostly focusing on curative health care. Chittagong is the exception and has the largest 
network of urban health care facilities funded by city corporations. Other health facilities include 
medical college hospitals, district hospitals, mother and child welfare centers, sub-district health 
complexes, city corporation and municipal health facilities, railway, police, military hospitals and 
clinics, and other clinics at work places. Although the list is long, the number and coverage of 
these  facilities  are  not  substantial  and  the  national  government’s  essential  service  package 
(ESP) in urban areas has primarily focused on immunization activities.  
 
7. 
 Commercial Sector. The commercial sector plays an important role in providing urban 
health  care,  mainly  through  graduate  private  practitioners,  pharmacies,  and  private  clinics. 
Other  private  health  care  providers  include  private  hospitals  (including  private  medical  college 
hospitals)  and  nongraduate  private  practitioners  (including  paramedics,  midwives,  nurses, 
charlatans, traditional birth attendants and homeopaths). Social marketing companies distribute 
temporary family planning methods through commercial channels.  
 
D. 
 
8. 
The range of publicly financed primary health facilities in urban areas has always been 
modest at best and nil at worst in South Asia. Bangladesh was no exception until a few years 
ago. While most of the country’s tertiary care infrastructure is in the main cities, there are just 
90–95  mother  and  child  welfare  centers  and  35–40  urban  dispensaries  focusing  entirely  on 
primary  care.  By  contrast,  rural  areas  have  almost  6,000  primary  care  service  delivery  points. 
USAID and  ADB each have large NGO-based urban health projects designed to fill the urban 
vacuum in noncommercial health care. The USAID project started in 1997 and the ADB project 
in 1999.  The USAID project is under MOHFW, and the ADB project under the Ministry of Local 
Government,  Rural  Development,  and  Cooperatives  (MOLGRDC).  They  remain  the  two  main 
contributors to urban health outside the commercial sector.  
 
 

Urban Primary Health Care 

 

 26 

        Appendix 2 

Urban Health-Related Policy Environment and Coordination 

E. 
 
9. 
Local  Governments  and  Urban  Primary  Health  Care.  The  Municipal  Administration 
Ordinance  of  1960,  Pourashava  Ordinance  of  1977,  and  City  Corporation  Ordinance  of  1983 
assigned responsibility for provision of preventive health care and limited curative care in urban 
areas  to  the  city  corporations  and  municipalities.  MOHFW  has  retained  responsibility  for 
defining  health  policies,  strategies,  and  technical  standards,  and  for  distributing  vaccines  and 
family planning items. Municipal governments normally view “urban health” services as limited 
to  immunization  and  water  and  sanitation  (i.e.,  environmental  health)  concerns.  Most 
municipalities  have  an  officer  in  charge  of  these  functions;  some  municipalities  also  have  a 
qualified  municipal  medical  officer  in  the  same  department  who  provides  closer  oversight  of 
medical issues, particularly the expanded program on immunization.  
 
10. 
Coordination.  The  level  of  coordination  and  cooperation  between  MOHFW  and  the 
Local Government Division of MOLGRDC—which oversees municipalities and their functions—
varies widely. The current approach to urban health was not systematically planned but evolved 
and  is  characterized  by  blurred  responsibilities  and  a  fragmented  structure.  It  has  no 
overarching urban health strategy or clear definitions of “urban area” or ”urban health.”  
 
11. 
Health,  Nutrition,  and  Population  Sector  Program  and  Urban  Health.  
The conceptual framework for MOHFW’s new program has been developed and will eventually 
lead  to  detailed  plans  for  the  next  6  years  in  the  health  sector.  An  urban  component  is  being 
contemplated for the first time (the earlier Health and Population Sector Program focused only 
on  rural  health).  The  new  program’s  conceptual  framework  indicates  that  the  Government  will 
consider expanding the role of contracted NGOs in urban areas.  
 
12. 
Role  of  Government.  MOHFW  and  MOLGRDC  are  not  central  to  service  delivery  in 
urban areas. It would be too costly and time-consuming to contemplate significantly building up 
the  Government  role  in  service  delivery.  However,  the  Government  is  critical  to  providing 
options  for  PHC  for  the  urban  poor.  The  Government  could  build  a  publicly  subsidized  urban 
PHC  network  with  the  many  existing  NGOs  and  commercial  players.  The  models  pioneered 
under  the  first  Urban  Primary  Health  Care  Project,  where  publicly  subsidized  urban  PHC  was 
provided  by  contracting-out  services  to  NGOs,  can  be  scaled  up  to  increase  the  depth  of 
coverage  (reach  more  poor  in  the  already  covered  areas)  as  well  as  the  width  (increase 
coverage to new areas). 
 
Government will, however, play a vital role in urban health through: (i) regulation, as in 
13. 
setting standards and approving service protocols, laying down health policy, developing long-
term  strategy,  and  thereby  guiding  the  development  of  urban  health  approaches;  and 
(ii) coordination,  as  in  determining  clients’  health  needs  in  urban  areas,  defining  catchment 
areas, and facilitating local supervision and support service provision. 
 
F. 
 
Reaching  the  Poor.  Health  services  must  be  brought  to  more  poor  and  vulnerable 
14. 
people in urban areas. The poor and vulnerable are not necessarily driven primarily by concerns 
about  preventive  care  but  by  their  need  for  housing,  clean  water,  sanitation,  a  clean 
environment,  etc.  Slum  dwellers  are  usually  migrants  from  rural  areas  and  are  mobile.  Other 
urban poor, who are not well captured by the system, are also believed to be fairly mobile.  
 

Issues and Challenges in Urban Health Care 

 

 Appendix 2 

27

15.  Widening  Geographical  Coverage.  There  are  probably  40–50  municipalities  of  a 
significant  size  not  captured  by  ADB  or  USAID  projects.  There  are  another  150  largely  rural 
municipalities  completely  outside  the  net.  The  NGO-led  projects  are  not  the  only  source  of 
services but the other players are rarely able to provide coverage at the basic standard needed 
to meet the nation’s health objectives. The commercial sector offers nationwide coverage but is 
rarely focused on providing primary health care or on offering affordable prices.  
 
16. 
Contracting  Service  Providers.  Continuity  and  cost  recovery  were  the  two  issues  to 
emerge  most  strongly  from  experiences  in  contracting-out  services.  The  NGO  community 
continually  faces  disruptions  caused  by  projects  ending  and  restarting.  Three-  to  3-year 
contracts are therefore seen as too short for proper planning and 6-year contracts are preferred. 
The  trade-off  between  cost  recovery  and  serving  the  poor  is  a  constant  source  of  pressure. 
NGOs are caught between pressures to serve the poor and to recover their costs for long-term 
survival.  Because  of  PHC  services’  public-good  characteristics  and  their  pro-poor  focus, 
substantial public subsidy will always be necessary. However, 10–15% of the total cost can be 
met  from  user  fees  from  people  who  can  afford  the  services.  The  remaining  85–90%  will  be 
used to fund free services for the poor and will come from the central Government (about 65%), 
and local governments (the remainder). 
 
17. 
Using United Nation’s population projections, various scenarios for costing were used to 
project  the  cost.  Two  levels  of  coverage  were  used:  50%  (mainly  the  poor)  and  100%  of  the 
urban  population.  Four  levels  of  per  capita  cost  were  used:  from  a  bare  minimum  of  $1  per 
capita  to  $30  per  capita  (close  to  the  recommendation  of  the  World  Health  Organization’s 
(WHO) Commission on Macroeconomics and Health), with $3 (current level of spending by the 
Government)  and  $12  (recommended  by  the  World  Development  Report,  1993)  in  between. 
The  projected  costs  are  given  below.  Even  at  $1  per  capita,  covering  only  50%  of  the 
population,  the  total  cost  comes  to  $16  million  a  year,  which  would  increase  to  $43  million  by 
2030 (Table A2).

At least 30% of the services to target the poor, otherwise 
contractual disincentives will be invoked under the partnership 
agreement. Monitoring and evaluation of inputs, outputs, 
outcomes, and impact to be disaggregated by poverty.

environmental health incorporated as pilot projects; and the poor 
exempted from user fees, and provided with free medicines. 

Behavior change communication and marketing activities 
strengthened with an additional component for branding and 
marketing of the UPHCP-I; outreach activities strengthened; and

Quality assurance and supportive supervision provided in the

The chief coordinator of the project to be an LGD officer of joint

Extension of the Project in four city corporations covered under 
UPHCP-I, and greater likelihood of cofinancing of Second Urban

partners. 
At least 30% of the services to target the poor through provision 
of free PHC services.

B. 
 
2. 
Baseline  Survey  of  the  Project  Area.  A  baseline  survey  will  be  conducted  by  the 
partner NGO at the beginning of the partnership agreement to identify poor households in the 
partnership  area.  Poor  households  will  be  identified  based  on  the  social  and  economic 
indicators  above.  These  households  will  be  given  entitlement  health  cards  giving  them  free 
access to health services under the Project. The survey of the poor households will be updated 
annually.  A  participatory  appraisal  will  be  conducted  at  the  community  level  to  assess  the 
availability  of  health  services;  access  to  health  services  by  the  poor;  and  the  social,  financial, 
and physical barriers to their use by the poor.  
 

 

 

 30 

 

Appendix 4 

Location  of  Health  Facilities  and  Mini-Clinics.  In  order  to  facilitate  their  use  by  the 
3. 
poor, health facilities will be located in slums or close to slums or poor populations. Where land 
is  scarce  and  health  facilities  cannot  be  located  in  or  near  slums,  mini-clinics  will  operate  in 
slums. Mini-clinics’ hours will be flexible to meet the needs of the poor. If necessary, they will be 
open during the evening. 
 
4. 
Social  Mobilization.  At  the  beginning  of  the  Project,  in  each  ward,  a  launching  or 
inception ceremony will introduce the health center facilities. A comprehensive community social 
mobilization program will be designed to disseminate basic information on project services and 
motivate  the  poor  to  use  the  health  facilities.  The  program  will  include  audiovisual  and  other 
innovative methods. Neighborhood meetings in slums and low-income areas will be organized 
periodically  to  explain  all  services  available,  rates  of  services,  and  free  services  for  the  poor. 
Networking  with  other  NGOs  in  the  area  will  be  encouraged  to  strengthen  pro-poor  targeting. 
Ward-level  primary  health  care  committees  with  male  and  female  ward  commissioners,  local 
leaders, members of youth clubs, civil society, NGOs, partner NGOs, and representatives of the 
poor will develop awareness campaigns for the poor and to monitor access to health services 
and their quality. The Project will support grassroots activities against social prejudice and other 
barriers that discourage use of health facilities by the poor and minorities.  
  
5. 
Monitoring  and  Record  Keeping.  The  partner  NGOs  will  keep  systematic  records  on 
the patients by poverty and gender, and will prepare quarterly reports of health service use by 
the poor, women, and adolescents.  
 
6. 
Capacity  Building.  The  field  staff  of  the  partner  NGOs  responsible  for  social 
mobilization,  health  education,  and  community  volunteers  will  be  oriented  on  the  Project  and 
pro-poor targeting. The field staff and volunteers will receive training in mobilizing the poor and 
generating demand for health services among them.  
 
C. 
 
7. 
The Project will ensure easy access to health-service-related information by the general 
public  and  the  urban  poor.  It  will  use  information  bulletin  boards  outside  health  facilities  to 
provide information on user fees and availability of free services to the poor, outreach activities, 
community-based  organizations,  and  other  cost-effective  means.  The  facility,  ward,  city,  and 
municipality PHC committees will include representatives of the poor urban slum dwellers and 
female  ward  members,  and  will  meet  quarterly.  The  committees  will  review  their  jurisdiction’s 
listing  of  poor  households  to  ensure  that  the  poor  are  being  targeted  efficiently,  the  annual 
physical  and  financial  plans  to  ensure  adaptation  to  the  local  context,  and  the  quarterly

4.

Single-Stage,  Two-Envelope  Process.  A  two-envelope  bidding  procedure  will  be 
adopted.  Bidders  are  to  submit  simultaneously  two  sealed  envelopes,  one  containing  the 
technical proposal(s) and one the financial proposal(s). Initially only the technical proposals will

the national bid evaluation committee.

will  determine  whether  the  proposals  are  technically  responsive  according  to  preestablished 
written  evaluation  criteria.  All  bidders  who  achieve  a  minimum  score  will  be  considered 
technically responsive.

Contract Award. The technical proposal score and the financial proposal will be used to 
calculate the overall score. Total points for the bidder’s technical proposal will be added to the 
total  points  for  the  bidder’s  financial  proposal.  The  highest  evaluated  proposal  will  be  the  one 
that comes closest to 200 possible points. The bid that results in the highest overall score will be 
offered the opportunity to enter into the contract. Where more than one bid receives the same 
overall  score,  the  one  with  the  highest  technical  proposal  score  will  be  awarded  the  contract.

Conditions for the Partnership Agreement 

If there is only one technically responsive bid for a particular partnership area, the bidder may 
be  offered  the  opportunity  to  enter  into  immediate  negotiation,  provided  that  the  financial 
proposal is comparable to that of the winning bidder of a similarly sized partnership area.
