Eligibility  to  Bid.  Bidders  should  meet  the  following  minimum  qualifying  criteria:  
(i) evidence of having implemented projects with a total annual value equal to $100,000 or more 
for  each  of  the  previous  5  years;  (ii)  evidence  that  the  organization  has  sound  financial 
accounting  practices;  (iii)  no  consistent  history  of  litigation  or  arbitration  awards  against  the 
bidder  or  associated  organizations;  (iv)  minimum  of  8  years’  experience  working  with  health 
systems and related activities, with at least 5 of these years in Bangladesh by principal bidder; 
and (v) registration with an appropriate agency of the Government, entitling the bidder to work in 
Bangladesh. 
 
Number  of  Agreements  per  Partner.  Bidders  may  submit  bids  for  up  to  four

Payment  and  Price  Adjustments.  Following  the  mobilization  payment,  partners  will 
receive  quarterly  payments  based on  the  partnership  agreement  price.  The  tender  documents 
and  contracts  will  include  different  cost  categories  such  as  salaries  of  staff,  cost  of  drugs, 
medical  instruments,  consumable  medical  supplies,  rent  payments,  operating  expenses, 
maintenance  costs,  etc.  A  lump-sum  payment  method  will  be  employed  to  reduce  the

will  ensure  that  the  services  are  being  provided  and  that  drugs  and  personnel  are  available.  
In  addition  to  regular  quarterly  payments,  a  bonus  will  be  paid  to  those  who  exceed

corporations,  municipalities,  the  PIU,  the  PMU,  and  ADB  to  have  access  to  inspect  records,

Targeting the Poor and Increasing their Access to PHC. The performance targets of 
the partnership agreement will specify levels of coverage to be achieved in terms of slum and

HIV/AIDS AND INFECTIOUS DISEASE CONTROL GRANT RATIONALE AND PURPOSE 

 

Rationale 

1. 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  finance  $10  million  of  project  costs  from  the 
portion of the Asian Development Fund (ADF) IX Grant Allocation dedicated to HIV/AIDS1 and 
other infectious disease control activities. This Appendix describes the rationale, purpose, and 
monitoring and evaluation plan for the grant-funded components of the Project.  
 
A. 
 
2. 
Alignment  with  Country’s  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy.  The  Bangladesh  Interim 
Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper2 (I-PRSP) highlights several key concerns that would in part 
be  addressed  by  the  Second  Urban  Primary  Health  Care  Project  (the  Project):  worsening  of 
urban  poverty  during  second  half  of  1990s  caused  by  negative  growth  in  per  capita  real 
consumption, widening socioeconomic differentials in mortality and malnutrition; poor quality of 
public  health  services,  and  weaknesses  in  the  health  sector,  in  particular  reproductive  health 
care.3  
 
3. 
Partnership  Agreement,  and  Country  Strategy  and  Program.  The  Government  of 
Bangladesh  and  ADB  signed  a  Partnership  Agreement  on  Poverty  Reduction  (PAPR)  in  April 
2000.4  The  PAPR  identified  the  Government’s  medium-term  goals  as  to  reduce  maternal 
mortality by 35%, infant mortality by 30%, and malnourishment among children by 20%, as well 
as  to  increase  the  proportion  of  women  of  appropriate  age  with  access  to  reproductive  health 
services  by  50%.  As  identified  in  the  Bangladesh  Country  Strategy  and  Program  Update  for 
2005–2006,5  HIV/AIDS,  nutrition,  and  urban  primary  health  care  (PHC)  are  ADB’s  social 
development  priorities  in  the  country.  They  will  be  addressed  by,  among  others,  building  local 
government capacity to deliver high-quality services to the urban poor, particularly women and 
children, in partnership with nongovernment organizations (NGOs). 
 
3. 
Infectious  Disease  Control.  Approximately  90%  of  the  services  provided  under  the 
partnership  agreement  are  from  the  essential  services  package  (ESP)  of  primary  health  care 
(Supplementary Appendix B). More than 50% of the Project’s base costs will address infectious 
diseases and HIV/AIDS control. The environment health subcomponent ($1.5 million), involving 
construction of community latrines and community-based solid waste disposal, will help control 
infectious diseases.  
 
HIV/AIDS  Control.  Although  HIV/AIDS  prevalence  in  Bangladesh  is  less  than  0.2%,  
4. 
this should not lead to complacency. The global HIV/AIDS pandemic has taught us that in every 
country the disease initially affects high-risk groups, and then spreads to the general population. 
The  window  of  opportunity  for  controlling  HIVAIDS  in  many  developing  member  countries  is 
precisely  when  prevalence  is  still  restricted  to  high-risk  groups  (e.g.,  injecting  drug  users,

commercial sex workers). This fairly describes the current situation in Bangladesh, and failure to 
address this major public health issue early in the epidemiological cycle will entail high human 
and economic costs. 
 
Millennium  Development  Goals  and  Human  Poverty  Reduction.  The  Project 
5. 
addresses  key  health  concerns  of  the  urban  poor,  especially  the  most  vulnerable  groups, 
women  and  children,  who  will  constitute  more  than  75%  of  the  beneficiaries.  The  Project  will 
help Bangladesh to achieve Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) 4, 5, and 6 (child mortality; 
maternal  mortality;  and  HIV/AIDS,  malaria  and  other  diseases).  The  Project  is  thus  closely 
aligned with ADB’s overarching goal of reducing poverty.  
 
6. 
Public–Private  Partnership,  Efficiency  Gains,  and  Policy  Implications  for  the 
Region. There is also a strong economic rationale for funding primary health care. Sound public 
health interventions lead to positive externalities and public goods. However, research findings 
vary  in  terms  of  how  such  “publicly”  subsidized  social  services,  including  primary  health  care, 
should  be  provided.  Recent  ADB  research  in  Cambodia  showed  that,  when  compared  with 
government-run  rural  health  facilities,  those  contracted  out  to  NGOs  were  more  effective.6 
Through  performance-based  contracting  to  NGOs,  the  Project  rewards  good  performance  by 
requiring accountability for effective, efficient social services delivery. The Project is consistent 
with ADB’s emphasis on development effectiveness and managing for development results. 
 
7. 
Local Government Ownership. Involvement of decentralized institutions in the delivery 
of  social  services,  including  primary  health  care,  improves  targeting  of  services  at  the  poor.7  
By  involving  city  corporations  and  municipalities  in  delivering  primary  health  care,  the  Project 
therefore follows one of the cardinal principles of development effectiveness.  
 
8. 
Funding  Agency  Assistance.  
The  components  of  the  Project  funded  by  the  ADF  IX  Grant  Program  are  well  aligned  with,  
but  will  not  replace,  the  resources  and  mandates  of  other  international  entities  operating  in 
Bangladesh. To ensure complementarity with ongoing efforts, the project management unit will 
maintain close coordination with the National AIDS Committee, Technical Advisory Committee, 
and the Sexually Transmitted Disease (STD)/AIDS  Program Unit in the Ministry  of Health and 
Family Welfare. 
 
B. 
 
9. 
Activities  will  be  supported  by  the  grant  through  the  following  project  components: 
(i) provision of PHC under the partnership agreement, and (ii) behavior change communication 
and marketing (BCCM) (Table A6). Under PHC service provision, the service delivery contract 
with  NGOs  will  include  two  activities  funded  entirely  by  the  grant:  $2.5  million  to  operate  
24 voluntary counseling and testing centers, one for each partnership area; and $5.0 million to 
control  sexually  transmitted  infections  (STI)  and  reproductive  tract  infections  (RTI).  Under  the 
BCCM component, the grant will provide $2.5 million for HIV/AIDS, STI and infectious disease 
control. A brief description of grant-funded activities follows.

10. 
enable people to make informed decisions about their HIV status and to take action. If a person 
decides to take the HIV test, VCT enables confidential testing. Counseling for VCT consists of 
pre-test, post-test, and follow-up counseling. VCT will benefit individuals and society as a whole 
by  helping  prevent  HIV/AIDS  and  STI.  Under  the  Project,  VCT  will  follow  the  national  policy 
established by the National AIDS Committee. 
 
11. 
STI and RTI Control. Services will be provided as a distinct component of the service 
contract with the NGOs and will include: (i) education of service providers and field workers in 
STI  and  RTI  control;  (ii)  diagnosis  and  management  of  STIs,  and  female  and  male  RTIs;  
and  (iii) counseling,  treatment,  and  motivating  clients  to  bring  their  partners  for  treatment  and 
counseling.  
 
12. 
BCCM  for  HIV/AIDS  and  STI  Control.  This  will  target  the  general  adult  population  as 
well  as  the  high-risk  population.  The  following  are  the  objectives  for  HIV  and  STI  control: 
(i) improve  the  vulnerable  population’s  knowledge,  attitudes,  and  behaviors  related  to  HIV; 
(ii) promote  condom  use;  (iii)  encourage  voluntary  counseling  and  HIV  testing;  (iv)  encourage 
care-seeking for STIs; (v) increase knowledge of the link between STIs and HIV; (vi) empower 
vulnerable people to control their lives; and (vii) enable tolerance and care toward people living 
with  HIV/AIDS.  Activities  supported  by  the  grant  will  help  households  prevent  adult  and  child 
infectious diseases through changes in knowledge, attitudes, and practices.

SUMMARY OF ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSES1   

Urban  populations 

increasing  (Appendix  2). 

in  Bangladesh  are  rapidly 

Urban Primary Health Care Sector Finance 

 
A. 
 
1. 
In  city 
corporations and major municipalities, the existing public infrastructure has been unable to cope 
with  the  rapid  influx  of migrants.  Provision  of  public  primary  health  care  (PHC)  in  urban  areas 
has  been  limited,  mainly  as  a  result  of  financial  constraints  of  city  corporations  and 
municipalities.  Urban  PHC 
is  provided  mainly  by  city  corporations,  nongovernment 
organizations  (NGOs),  and  the  private  sector  but  has  a  weak  financial  base.  PHC  operations 
are  financially  supported  through  partnership  agreements  with  the  Local  Government  Division 
(LGD),  direct  financing  by  local  governments,  direct  assistance  from  international  donors,  
or user charges. The LGD budget for agreements is financed from the project fund with foreign 
assistance.  Local  governments,  including  city  corporations  and  municipalities,  receive  grants 
from the central Government, which generally contributes more than a quarter of their revenue. 
In other words, urban PHC depends heavily on foreign assistance and grants from the central 
Government. 
 
A  significant  proportion  of  local  governments’  budget  relies  on  grants  from  the  central 
2. 
Government.2  Other  sources  of  revenue  are  taxes,  rates,  fees,  and  charges  levied  locally. 
Urban local governments raise 55–75% of their revenue from their own sources; the remainder 
comes from grants from LGD and Annual Development Program. Local governments allocate a 
large proportion of their budget to physical infrastructure (30–40%) and public health accounts 
for only 15–20 per cent.3 Expenditure for urban PHC from the public health budget of the local 
governments  is,  however,  negligible,  as  no  local  government  under  the  first  Urban  Primary 
Health  Care  Project  (UPHCP-I),  except  Chittagong,  was  able  to  offer  matching  budgetary 
support. If urban PHC is to be sustained or expanded to meet the needs of the increasing urban 
population in the four largest cities and other urbanized municipalities, additional foreign aid or 
other sources of income will have to be sought. 
 
Rationale  for  Public  Intervention  in  PHC.  There  are  three  strong  reasons  why  the 
3. 
public  sector  should  support  urban  PHC.  First,  PHC  focuses  on  services  with  large  positive 
externalities  and  public-good  characteristics,  such  as  immunization  programs  and  health 
education.  As  society  will  benefit  from  the  provision  of  PHC,  the  Government  should  bear  an 
appropriate  level  of  the  cost.  Second,  PHC  provision  will  help  to  control  diseases,  including 
tuberculosis,  malaria,  and  diarrhea,  which  are  particularly  prevalent  among  the  poor.  
This  means  that  public  expenditure  on  PHC  is  likely  to  be  spent  on  the  poor,  thereby 
encouraging a more equitable redistribution of national wealth. Third, the potential productivity 

                                                 
1  See Supplementary Appendix K for more details. 
2  Local Government Division (LGD) obtains a significant portion of the ministerial budget. The budget of  Ministry of 
Local  Government,  Rural  Development  and  Cooperatives  (MOLGRDC)  has  been  9%  to  10%  of  the  total 
Government budget in the last 4 financial years, and was Tk49 billion in FY2005. MOLGRDC allocates 86% to 89% 
of its budget, or Tk42 billion, to LGD. In contrast, the budget required for urban primary health care (PHC) is small. 
The  LGD  budget  consists  of  a  small  current  expenditure  budget  (10–15%)  and  a  large  annual  development 
program budget (85–90%). LGD has allocated 1% to 2% of its annual development program budget to urban PHC, 
which has covered capital and operational costs of service delivery through partnership agreements. Of the urban 
PHC budget, 75% to 80% has been financed by foreign aid. LGD allocates just less than a quarter of its current 
expenditure budget to grants for autonomous bodies and institutions, which includes local governments. 

3  Country  paper:  Bangladesh,  Local  Government  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific:  A  Comparative  Study,  UNESCAP. 

Available: http://www.unescap.org/huset/lgstudy/country/bangladesh/bangladesh.html 

 

 44 

 Appendix 11 

Economic Analysis 

gains realized through health improvement are substantial, raising the amount of social benefit 
far above the profit of private PHC providers. Without support from the public sector, the supply 
of PHC services is likely to be suboptimal.  
 
Contracting-out  of  Health  Services.4  Experience  suggests  that  outsourcing  will 
4. 
improve the flexibility and cost-effectiveness of PHC service delivery. The “contact-out model” is 
more cost-effective than the “contract-in model.”5 The contract-in model, where partners provide 
only management support to civil service health staff and are obliged to follow government rules 
and  regulations  with  respect  to  the  government-provided  resources,  is  inflexible  in  delivering 
services.  The  contract-out  model,  however,  in  which  partners  are  responsible  for  the  entire 
management and delivery of PHC services, allows for more flexible employment management 
and  greater  innovation.  As  the  UPHCP-I  was  based  on  the  contract-out  model,  the  Project 
should build upon its successes.  
 
B. 
 
5. 
Disability-adjusted  Life  Years  (DALYs).  An  attempt  was  made  to  estimate  DALYs 
saved to assess the cost-effectiveness of the project design. Since the Project especially aims 
to  improve  child  and  maternal  health  care,  a  significant  proportion  (80.1%)  of  DALYs  will  be 
saved from reducing the infant, under-5, and maternal mortality and the child malnutrition rates. 
Control of communicable diseases through the essential services package  will also help reduce 
DALYs. In total, the Project will decrease 2.3 million DALYs or 16% of the estimated “without-
project” DALYs over the next 20 years. The cost per DALY saved for the Project is estimated at 
$35,  which  is  compatible  with  the  estimation  for  the  first  phase  of  the  Project  ($34  per  DALY 
saved) and well within the acceptable range listed in ADB’s Policy for the Health Sector. 
 
6. 
Economic Internal Rate of Return. To assess the economic viability and efficiency of 
the investment under the Project, economic benefits and costs were identified and an economic 
internal rate of return (EIRR) over 20 years was estimated. The Project will qualitatively improve 
urban  PHC  and  quantitatively  expand  its  coverage.  This  will  create  two  streams  of  economic 
benefit:  a  resource  cost  saving  and  productivity  gain.  As  a  result  of  qualitative  improvements,  
an  existing  urban  PHC  user  will  be  able  to  save  out-of-pocket  expenses  by  reducing  wasteful 
outpatient  visits,  treatments,  and  prescriptions.  The  saving  in  out-of-pocket  expenses  is 
assumed  to  be  $0.50  per  person  in  a  year  in  areas  covered  by  the  UPHCP,  and  $1.00  in  the 
additional areas covered by the Project.  
 
7. 
Quantitative expansion in PHC coverage will allow more people living in urban areas to 
access  PHC.  Project  beneficiaries  will  increase  from  30%  to  60%  of  the  population  in  project 
areas  and  from  20%  to  50%  in  new  areas.  Prevention  and  early  treatment  of  diseases  will 
reduce the mortality rate, and consequently keep the workforce in good health. To measure the 
impact  of  the  quantitative  expansion  in  monetary  terms,  the  income  gained  by  an  additional 
child under 5 years old, whose life was saved by the Project, has been calculated, based on the 
estimated  lifetime  earning  of  a  worker.  The  under-5  mortality  rate  is  assumed  to  decrease 
gradually over the 6 years of the Project toward the target level of 69.7% from the current level

8. 
The  estimated  total  economic  cost  of  the  Project  at  constant  2005  prices  is  
$178.1  million  for  20  years,  including  capital  and  incremental  recurrent  costs.  The  recurrent 
costs of the Project include: (i) operating and maintenance costs for civil works and equipment, 
which are set at 4% of investment costs, incurred every 5 years; (ii) salaries of managerial and 
administrative  staff;  (iii)  a  contracting  amount  for  partnership  agreements;  and  (iv)  monitoring 
and  evaluation  costs,  including  management  information  system  implementation  costs.  
The  Project  is  estimated  to  yield  a  net  present  value  of  $62.4  million  and  an  EIRR  of  17.4%, 
assuming  a  discount  rate  of  12.0%.  The  productivity  gains  are  much  larger  than  the  
out-of-pocket expenditure reduction, as saving the life of a child under 5 years old leads to the 
life-long  supply  of  one  labor  unit  after  the  child  enters  the  labor  market.  The  actual  economic 
rate  of  return  is  likely  to  be  higher,  reflecting  positive  externalities  and  longer-term 
intergenerational  social  benefits  that  come  with  improved  quality  of  PHC  services.  These 
benefits  may  be  reflected  in  education  outcomes  and  quality  of  life,  to  which  it  is  difficult  to 
assign monetary values. 
 
Sensitivity  Analysis.  A  sensitivity  analysis  has  been  undertaken  on  the  basis  of 
9. 
alternative  assumptions  about  improvements  to  the  quality  and  coverage  of  PHC  services. 
Quality  improvement  is  reflected  in  the  resource  savings.  The  “low”  case  for  PHC  quality 
assumes that resource savings are 10% lower than the target, and the “high” case 10% greater. 
The “low” case for coverage shows that the number of beneficiaries is 10% lower than planned, 
and the “high” case 10% higher. The findings of the sensitivity analysis indicate that the return is 
more sensitive to changes in the extent of coverage. An increase in coverage brings productivity 
gains and savings of total out-of-pocket expenditures, while an increase in quality affects only 
expenditure  savings.  Therefore,  for  the  successful  outcome  of  the  Project,  it  is  crucial  to 
cultivate latent demand and increase coverage for the poor who do not currently have enough 
access to PHC services.

($139.4  million)  and  other  PHC  service  providers  (–$4.0  million).  The  Government  also  bears 
the financial cost of the Project ($74.6 million) and, therefore, the Government and the economy 
lose about $73.0 million. The net total economic effect is $62.4 million.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 

Introduction 

Description of the Project 

A.  
 
In compliance with Asian Development Bank (ADB) environmental requirements, an initial 
1. 
environmental  examination  (IEE)  was  conducted  for  the  Project,  which  is  classified  under 
environmental  category  B  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Operations  Manual  Section  F1/OP. 
Subcomponents  to  be  financed  under  the  Project  show  no  significant  environmental  impacts. 
Project  activities  that  may  have  a  marginal  effect,  and  the  main  mitigation  measures  proposed, 
are  summarized  here.  Overall,  the  project  is  expected  to  result  in  substantial  environmental 
benefits. The IEE is in agreement with ADB’s Environmental Guidelines (2003) and Bangladesh’s 
laws  and  regulations  (Supplementary  Appendix  G).  The  summary  IEE  summarizes  the 
environmental  issues,  mitigation  measures,  institutional  arrangements,  and  environmental 
monitoring plan.  
 
B. 
 
2. 
The Project will provide primary health care (PHC) to unserved urban populations with a 
special focus on areas of poverty and bad environmental quality. The Project continues the model 
pioneered by the first urban primary health care project (UPHCP-I), under which service providers 
were  contracted  to  deliver  an  agreed-on  essential  service  package  (ESP)  through  partnership 
agreements  to  service  areas.  The  Project  will  provide  PHC  by  contracting-out  services  to 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and provide PHC infrastructure and environmental health 
facilities.  The  Project  will  construct  at  least  50  new  PHC  centers,  14  new  comprehensive 
reproductive health care (CRHC) centers and upgrade 4 PHC centers to CRHC centers. It will be 
implemented over 6.5 years, beginning in July 2005. Rented accommodation will be reviewed for 
suitability  as  clinics,  and  new  land  will  be  required  for  construction.  The  specifics  are  still  to  be 
determined.  The  Project  will:  (i)  support  the  construction  of  at  least  four  community  toilets  with 
bathing  and  urinal  facilities  in  each  partnership  area;  (ii) support  pilot  community-based  solid 
waste  management  through  community  mobilization  and  provision  of  dustbins  and  collection 
trolleys;  and  (iii)  support  municipalities  to  improve  clinical  waste  management  by  formulating 
clinical waste management plans, providing training, and supplying waste segregation equipment 
(bins) in health care facilities.  
 
C. 
 
3. 
Bangladesh  is  flat,  except  for  the  hills  along  its  eastern  borders,  and  is  vulnerable  to 
massive  flooding.  Urban  infrastructure  is  inadequate  for  the  present  and  future  population  and 
industrial  requirements.  Less  than  50%  of  Dhaka’s  solid  waste  is  collected,  and  the  country’s 
wastes  are  expected  to  rise  by  eight  to  ten  times  by  2020.  The  city’s  sewerage  system  covers 
only one third of its area, and 30% of the capital’s people use either open latrines or none at all. 
Only half the people who live in cities have access to safe water, and urban demand for water is 
expected  to  rise  over  six  times  by  2020.  The  subproject  sites  have  no  significant  vegetation, 
steep slopes, or flood-prone areas. Endangered species and other wildlife are not affected. Some 
sites lie within low to moderate earthquake zones. The project area has no cultural heritage sites. 
 
D. 
 
4. 
Location. PHC centers need to be close to slums and other areas inhabited by the urban 
poor. However, scarcity of land and pressure to accept donated land sometimes leads to facilities

being  located  far  from  urban  poor  areas.  Although  medical  facilities  are  small  and  will  not 
necessarily involve dislocation of inhabitants, in some cases squatters may be evicted, for whom 
adequate rehabilitation and resettlement safeguards will be need. Resettlement will be minimal, 
and any involuntary resettlements that occur will be mitigated in accordance with the measures 
stipulated  under  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary  resettlement  and  the  Handbook  on  Resettlement:  
A Guide to Good Practice. Before finalizing site selection, the project management unit (PMU) will 
delineate  the  partnership  areas  and  their  estimated  population  using  existing  maps.  This  will 
enable  the  proposed  location  of  PHC  centers  to  be  checked  against  potential  demand  and  the 
walking distance for the urban poor users to be estimated. The ground floors will be higher than 
the flood level identified using data from the past 5 years. The sites will also receive sufficient fill 
to bring them above 30 centimeters above the surrounding land for rain runoff. 
 
5. 
Design  and  Construction.  Existing  CRHC  center  facilities  do  not  have  hand  basins  in 
wards,  showers  for  in-patients,  stretcher  access  between  operating  theatres  or  recovery  wards 
and the general wards on the floor above, or laundry rooms. No major construction impacts are 
foreseen  given  that  buildings  are  small.  Site  construction  activities  such  as  digging  of  drains  or 
landfill site landscaping will generate dust, noise, and vibration that will affect workers on site and 
the  nearby  population,  while  soil  erosion  may  result  from  land  preparation.  To  mitigate  these 
impacts,  dust  suppression  techniques  such  as  water  sprays,  covered  wagons  and  skips  will  be 
used,  working  hours  agreed,  plant  and  equipment  with  low  operating  noise  levels  used,  and 
excavation and land leveling works limited during the rainy season. No construction camps will be 
necessary.  Measures  will  be  taken  for  the  following:  (i)  site  stabilization,  erosion,  and  runoff;  
(ii)  dust  and  noise  suppression;  (iii)  management  of  traffic  and  utilities;  and  (iv)  worker  safety. 
Good  health  and  hygiene  practices  at  work  and  measures  to  prevent  work  accidents  will  be 
achieved through an occupational health and safety plan (OHSP), which will include emergency 
plans, personnel basic training, and first aid provisions. 
 
6. 
The following provisions will be considered at the design stage to strengthen existing and 
proposed project facilities: (i) monitoring of on-site drinking water quality; (ii) provision of mosquito 
and  fly  screens  to  all  window  and  door  openings;  (iii)  provision  of  wash  basins  in  examination 
rooms; (iv) provision of showers for patients and laundry rooms in CRHC centers; (v) provision of 
storage cabinets with smooth surfaces and doors; (vi) where noise and/or fumes reach operation 
and  recovery  rooms  of  CRHC  centers,  fitting  of  plastic-framed  double-glazed  windows,  and  air 
conditioners;  (vii) use  of  high-quality  material  during  construction;  and  (viii)  appropriate  septic 
tank and sanitation scheme selection.

8. 
Clinical  infectious  waste  (CIW)  release  has  an  important  impact  on  the  environment. 
Although  CIW  from  all  hospitals,  clinics,  and  laboratories  is  a  small  proportion  of  overall  solid 
wastes,  it  is  extremely  hazardous.  CIW  is  often  mixed  with  normal  solid  wastes  at  medical 
facilities  and  taken  to  the  city  dumps.  All  dumps  are  uncontrolled;  there  are  no  properly 
engineered dumps or sanitary landfills. Waste pickers and animals roam the dumps, and are at 
high  risk  of  contracting  disease.  Used  syringes,  tubes,  and  bags  are  sold  by  scavengers  and 
hospital staff members to dealers who repackage and sell them as new to medical facilities and to 
drug users. Some project cities have begun clinical waste management (CWM) programs, which 
will  be  supported  under  the  Project  for  selected  town  and  cities.  The  CWM  plans  will  address 
handling  and  collection,  storage,  segregation,  treatment,  and  disposal  of  medical  waste  at  the 
municipal  level.  They  will  include  an  analysis  of  clinical  waste  generation  and  facility 
management, and examine alternative options for transport, treatment and disposal, institutional 
and  financing  arrangements,  and  initial  awareness-raising.  Training  will  be  provided  under  the 
Project to health workers and communities. 
 
9. 
Short-term measures to improve CWM in the project clinics will include:  (i) designation of 
a  person  in  charge  of  waste  management  in  each  clinic;  (ii)  regular  training  for  all  staff;  
(iii) provision of color-coded, covered receptacles in strategic positions for separate categories of 
waste; (iv) daily internal collection and storage of containers within the clinic compound, which will 
be in a fenced, secured area; (v) collection and transportation of clinical waste containers by the 
city  corporation  and  municipal  conservancy  department,  and  burial  in  separate  pits  for  different 
wastes in a fenced, secured area of the municipal dumpsite; (vi) return of containers and invoice 
of  services  to  the  clinic,  and  (vii)  cleansing  of  containers  by  the  clinic.  An  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) plan and schedule will be prepared for each center, specifying environmental 
monitoring  tasks  (e.g.,  regular  cleaning  of  external  perimeter  drains,  ensuring  that  they  are 
connected to off-site drains), frequency of monitoring, responsibilities, and costs. The O&M plan 
will be incorporated into the partnership agreements, and monitored as part of the assessment of 
partners’ performance.  
 
10. 
Operational  Maintenance.  Community  toilets  will  be  fitted  with  suitably  designed  septic 
tanks  or  sewerage  connections.  Regular  maintenance  will  ensure  appropriate  functioning  of  the 
schemes and prevent pests, disease vectors, and odors. Proper construction, regular collection, 
and maintenance of dustbins will be necessary to ensure there are no visual or odor disturbances 
to neighboring areas, and to repel rodents and insects, which carry diseases.

the  Neighborhood  Environment.

G.

RESETTLEMENT FRAMEWORK 

Project Background and Description 

 
A. 
 
The Second Urban Primary Health Care Project (the Project) addresses the unmet need 
1. 
for  primary  health  care  (PHC)  in  urban  areas  of  Bangladesh,  especially  among  the  poor.  
The Project will finance 64 civil works subprojects: 50 PHC and 14 comprehensive reproductive 
health  care (CRHC)  centers  in  all  six  city  corporations  and five  municipalities.  The Project  will 
support  the  purchase  of  12  apartments  for  PHC  centers  in  Dhaka,  and  upgrading  of  4  PHC 
centers  to  CRHC  centers;  neither  activity  involves  resettlement.  Fifty  community  toilets  will  be 
constructed  in  the  slums  of  the  project  area.  The  health  facilities  to  be  constructed  under  the 
Project  are  designed  for  land-scarce  urban  settings.  The  total  land  requirement  under  the 
Project will be approximately 3 hectares.1  
 
No involuntary resettlement is expected as a result of the Project.2  As in the first Urban 
2. 
Primary  Health  Care  Project  (UPHCP-I),  under  which  128  facilities  were  constructed  on 
unoccupied government and donated land, almost all the construction under the Project will be 
done  on  unoccupied  government  or  donated  land.  However,  a  contingency  is  provided  for  
25  project-affected  people  in  the  six  city  corporations  and  five  municipalities.  In  the 
municipalities,  five  CRHC  and  25  PHC  centers  will  be  constructed.  A  short  resettlement  plan 
has been prepared for the six city corporations. It will serve as a model for addressing potential 
resettlement issues in the subprojects of five municipalities (Supplementary Appendix I).3  
 
B. 
 
3. 
The  legislation  governing  land  acquisition  for  public  purposes  is  the  Acquisition  and 
Requisition  of  Immovable  Property  Ordinance  (Ordinance  II  of  1982)  and  its  amendments  in 
1993  and  1994.  The  ordinance  is  the  only  law  that  governs  all  cases  of  acquisition  and 
requisition by the Government of immovable property (land, crops, and built structures) for any 
public  purpose  or  in  the  public  interest.  The  ordinance  does  not  cover  project-affected  people 
without  title  or  ownership  records,  such  as  informal  settlers  or  squatters.  In  most  cases,  
the compensation does not constitute the market or replacement value of the property acquired.  
In  the  absence  of  a  Government  policy  consistent  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
policies  on  involuntary  resettlement,  poverty  reduction,  and  social  development,  a  project-
specific  resettlement  policy  framework  and  resettlement  procedure  guidelines  will  be  adopted. 
The framework and guidelines in this appendix will apply to all subprojects to be prepared and 
approved  under  the  Project.  It  will  ensure  that  people  affected  by  land  acquisition  who 
permanently  or  temporarily  lose  their  livelihoods  will  be  eligible  for  appropriate  compensation 
under the Project.

The resettlement policy framework reflects the Government’s land acquisition laws and 
4. 
regulations and  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary  resettlement  and  guidelines.  It  stipulates  eligibility 
and provisions for all types of losses (land, crop, trees, fish, structures, business, employment, 
work  days,  wages,  and  social  infrastructure).  Land  for  land  will  not  be  feasible  because 
replacement land is not available. Lost livelihood will be compensated at full replacement cost, 
which  will  help  the  project-affected  people  to  rehabilitate  themselves.  Project-affected 
households  compensated  by  the  district  deputy  commissioner  for  lost  assets  will  receive:

such as allowance and compensation for loss of business, work days, and income because of 
dislocation. Households headed by females, and other vulnerable households will be eligible for 
cash  assistance  to  relocate  and  to  reconstruct  houses  or  structures.  Table  A13.2  shows  the 
measures  adopted  in  the  resettlement  plan  on  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  to  bridge  the 
gap  between  the  ADB  policy  on  involuntary  resettlement  and  the  Government  policy  on  land 
acquisition, and assessment and valuation of acquired property.

There  are  specific  resettlement  procedural  guidelines  to  guide  the  preparation  of  resettlement

The resettlement procedure guidelines require: (i) an initial social assessment survey by Local

The  short  resettlement  plan  must,  however,  comply  with  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary 
resettlement and other social safeguard guidelines. 
 
The following safeguards will be applied to government and donated land: (i) consulting

fully on site selection with any project-affected people without titles; (ii) ensuring that voluntary

A.     Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the subsector to reduce poverty in Bangladesh: 
 
Catastrophic health shocks leading to hospitalization are an important dimension of vulnerability and impoverishment. 
The poor pay a significant share of their income for health services. However, their health status is substantially lower 
than  the  national  average,  and  their  access  to  health  services  is  marginal.  Only  in  the  last  decade  have  the 
Government  and  donors  started  addressing  urban  primary  health  care—an  area  that  continues  to  be  neglected  in 
other countries of South Asia. The interim-poverty reduction strategy identifies reduction of human poverty, including 
improving  access  and  quality  of  primary  health  care  (PHC)  to  the  poor,  as  a  key  priority  for  poverty  reduction. 
The poverty reduction partnership agreement between the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Government, and 
ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  identify  primary  health  as  a  key  area  for  Government  and  ADB  interventions. 
The Bangladesh health  policy (2000) stressed the  need for expanding  health services in urban areas,  especially for 
the poor. However, only 5.3% of Government expenditure relates to health, most of it targeted at the rural poor while 
the urban poor’s health needs are largely unmet by public interventions. 

 

The  Project  will  address  many  of  the  concerns  relating  to  PHC  for  the  urban  poor  by  strengthening  and  expanding 
public health services in urban areas. The Project will include new urban areas that have little or no access to publicly 
provided urban PHC. The Project will focus on PHC, which mainly benefits the poor and the urban population with no 
access to PHC services. Health centers  will be established near urban slums  with and will concentrate on the poor. 
The partnership agreement with nongovernment organizations (NGOs) will require at least 30% of their services to be 
provided to the poor. The partnership agreement will require targeting specific groups such as casual laborers, street 
vendors, rickshaw and van pullers, garbage collectors, maid servants, street sweepers, commercial sex workers, etc. 
PHC  will  cover  diseases  such  as  diarrhea  and  tuberculosis  (TB),  which  usually  affect  the  poor  and  vulnerable. 
The  Project  is  expected  to  improve  the  health  of  at  least  14  million  people  living  in  six  city  corporations  and  five 
municipalities by helping provide an essential package of health services. 

 
B.     Poverty Analysis                                                                         Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention 
         
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
The urban economy is driven by the growth of the overall national economy, which is, in turn, linked inescapably to the 
vagaries of the world economy. Bangladesh has recently benefited from globalization. However, the country is volatile 
as  it  adjusts  to  global  changes  and  this  will  be  reflected  first  of  all  in  the  urban  economy.  Changes  as  a  result  of 
globalization will push people into poverty as well as taking them out of it. The absolute number of households below 
the poverty line is falling in rural areas, but increasing in urban areas. This is mainly due to migration of the poor from 
rural  to  urban  areas  in  search  of  jobs.  Most  of  these  rural  migrants  settle  in  urban  slums  or  become  homeless  or 
squatters.  
 
There is abundant evidence of the strong and dynamic relationship between poverty and health.  This is particularly 
acute  when  rural  migrants  do  not  have  the  traditional  support  structures  of  social  networks  and  kinship  and  live  in 
unhygienic conditions. Providing the poor with social services alone is not enough. Most users of the services provided 
by the first Urban Primary Health Care Project (UPHCP-I) were either low- or middle-income urban households. Most 
poor pregnant women in slums continued to give birth at home, increasing the risk of maternal mortality and morbidity. 
However, the number of users of weekly satellite clinics in slums can be improved through community mobilization in 
slum  areas.  In  slums  and  squatter  settlements,  mini-clinics  will  need  to  operate  at  night  to  cater  to  the  needs  of 
working  women.  Discussions  with  the  urban  poor,  health  service  providers,  and  partner  NGOs  indicate  that  use  of 
health  services  by  the  urban  poor  is  influenced,  among  others,  by:  (i)  lack  of  money,  (ii)  lack  of  information  on 
available  health  services,  (iii)  cost  of  health  services,  (iv)  distance  to  the  health  facilities,  (v)  inflexible  hours  of  the 
health  facilities,  (vi)  social  prejudice  against  modern  and  established  health  facilities,  (vii)  dependence  on 
neighborhood drug stores, and (vii) reliance on traditional medicine.  
 

 

 Appendix 14 

57  

The  Project  will  support  operational  research  on  the  urban  poor  to  aid  design  of  effective  strategies  to  benefit  them 
through  PHC  services.  The  project  NGOs  will  be  encouraged  to  devise  approaches  and  procedures  to  expand 
services in slums and areas with many urban poor. The contract establishing the partnership agreement with NGOs 
will  include  specific  provisions  to  ensure  inclusion  of  the  poor  as  project  beneficiaries  (Appendix  4).  Measures  to 
improve  pro-poor  targeting  include:  (i)  baseline  survey  and  identification  of  the  urban  poor  in  the  project  areas, 
mapping of the potential target population, and introduction of entitlement cards; (ii) identification of constraints faced 
by the urban poor in accessing health services; (iii) promotion of basic health services daily in slums; (iv) community 
social mobilization activities to develop health awareness in slums; (v) social marketing to increase demand for health 
services  among  the  poor  living  in  slums;  (vi)  increasing  the  number  of  trained  community  organizers  and  health 
volunteers; (vii) facility-level health committees in slums and low-income urban areas for monitoring health services to 
the  poor,  and  representation  of  the  poor  on  the  committees;  (viii)  involvement  of  the  ward  commissioners, 
representatives  of  NGOs  and  civil  society,  and  the  poor  communities  in  monitoring  health  services  to  the  poor; 
(ix) setting  up  targets  for  NGO  outreach  workers  to  mobilize  the  poor  to  access  to  health  services;  (x)  independent 
monitoring to review access and quality of services to the poor; and (xi) an orientation program for all PHC providers 
to increase the understanding of the poor and planning of health services to the poor. 
 
To  improve  hygiene  in  the  project  area,  community  toilets  and  bathing  facilities  will  be  established  for  the  poor. 
The Project  will support community  waste  management efforts to reduce the amount of general  waste, especially in 
slums  and  low-income  areas.  The  project  activities  on  behavior  change,  communications,  and  marketing  will  create 
demand for PHC services among the poor. The campaign will address some of the sociocultural factors that prevent 
the poor, especially women and children, from accessing social services. The monitoring of PHC services will include 
records  of  poor  patients  seeking  services,  and  patients  will  be  disaggregated  by  income.  Mechanisms  for  regular 
monitoring  of  quality  of  health  services  and  access  to  health  services  for  the  poor  will  be  institutionalized  in 
neighborhood and ward committees. Experiences in mobilizing the urban poor to access health services will feed into 
the  development  of  operational  models  that  will  serve  as  the  basis  for  expanding  approaches  to  other  urban  areas. 
The Project will convey its front-line experience into higher-level discussions to make sure that adequate mechanisms 
are created for the voice of the poor to be heard in the higher-level structures. Ensuring the accountability of the health 
service providers to the poor will be a major priority for the Project.

Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
 
Is there a participation strategy? 
 
A  stakeholder  analysis  was  conducted  as  part  of  the  feasibility  study.  The  study  helped  to  identify  key  project 
stakeholders and to plan the project activities. Primary stakeholders include selected staff from the Ministry of Local 
Government,  Rural  Development,  and  Cooperatives;  Ministry  of  Health  and  Family  Welfare;  project  implementation 
unit  of  the  UPHPC-I;  NGOs  involved  in  the  UPHCP-I;  donor  consortium;  community-based  organizations; 
representatives and officers of city corporations and municipalities; and representatives of the poor and of vulnerable 
groups.  Stakeholders  include  relevant  line  ministries  and  other  private  providers  of  health  services.  During  project 
implementation,  participatory  processes  will  be  incorporated  into  mapping  target  beneficiaries  from  urban  slum  and 
low-income areas, and into monitoring health services through the neighborhood and ward health committees at the 
health facilities. Citizen score cards and routine display of up-to-date public information about staffing, stock, facilities, 
and  fee  rates  will  improve  accountability  of  the  service  providers  and  facilitate  participation  of  service  users  in 
monitoring services. 
 
 
D.     Gender Development 
 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Has an output been prepared? 
  
Maternal mortality is high: with a maternal mortality ratio of 300 per 100,000 live births, the estimated life-time risk of 
dying  from  pregnancy  and  childbirth-related  causes  is  about  100  times  higher  than  in  developed  countries. 
Bangladesh  has  traditionally  exhibited  low  rates  of  antenatal  care  and  births  in  health  facilities.  The  proportion  of 
pregnant women making at least one antenatal visit has improved to 37% in 2000, which leaves more than 2.5 million 
pregnancies  annually  lacking  any  antenatal  care.  Despite  significant  investments  in  basic  and  comprehensive 
essential obstetric care, only 6% of births take place in health facilities. Despite good progress in the last two decades, 
gaps  in  health  service  use  are  evident  in  child  health.  High  rates  of  malnutrition  continue  and  micronutrient 
deficiencies  remain.  Almost  half  of  the  women  and  78%  of  children  6–11  months  old  suffer  from  anemia;  45%  of 

 Yes 

 No 

 

 58 

 Appendix 14 

children under 5 years old are short for their age or stunted, while 18% are severely stunted. Bangladesh is far from 
achieving the Millennium Development Goal related to maternal mortality. 
Poor  women  lag  behind  men  in  most  indicators  of  well-being  and  are  disadvantaged  socially  and  economically. 
Women and adolescent girls suffer coercion, exploitation, and violence. The Project will address all these issues and 
explore ways to reduce their negative impacts on female health.  
 
The UPHCP-I showed that more than 75% of the health service users are  women since most project services  were 
covered under the essential service package (ESP). Major investments under ESP are for reproductive, maternal, and 
child health. The Project will focus on reducing the maternal mortality ratio and on promoting child survival and health. 
It will include activities to increase the number of poor women benefiting from health services, and improve the quality 
of  health  services  to  women  by  increasing  the  number  of  health  facilities  and  access  to  PHC  and  obstetric  care. 
The  project  facilities  will  provide  choice  of  temporary  and  permanent  contraception  and  reduce  unwanted  deliveries 
and their associated morbidity and mortality. The Project will explore and support the rights of women and girls in this 
context as well as develop mechanisms to secure these rights.  
 
Gender Plan. The Project will provide for an elaborate network of PHC and comprehensive reproductive health care 
(CRHC) centers, which will provide basic and comprehensive emergency obstetric care facilities for pregnant women, 
in  addition  to  antenatal  check-ups,  and  will  concentrate  on  extending  these  facilities  to  poor  women  and  girls. 
The Project will provide legal counseling for women who are abused or under the threat of being abused. It will explore 
ways  to  empower  women  to  protect  themselves  from  such  pressures.  At  least  50%  of  the  health  providers  of  the 
partner NGOs will be women, thus the Project will create jobs for women. Using a suitable poverty coverage model, 
the Project will allocate half its community bathing and toilet facilities to women. The female ward commissioners will 
be  involved  in  community  programs  to  raise  awareness  about  services  available  in  PHC  and  CRHC  centers.  Other 
forms of structured dialogue with poor women and girls will ensure that the Project is meeting their health needs.  
 
Community health volunteers will include women, especially from poor communities. The volunteers will be trained in 
motivational and community outreach activities. Sustainable incentive packages for the community volunteers will be 
developed under the partnership agreement. Women community leaders and ward commissioners will be involved in 
planning  community-based  solid  waste  management.  At  least  30%  of  the  national  project  steering  committee, 
project  management  unit  (PMU),  and  project  implementation  unit  will  be  women.  Of  the  chairs  of  ward  PHC 
coordination  committees,  at  least  30%  will  be  women,  and  all  the  committees  will  have  women  members. 
This  framework  will  be  augmented  by  other  accountability  structures  developed  under  the  Project  to  ensure  that  it 
identifies and meets the health needs of poor women and girls. Preference will be given to bids from NGO with female 
project managers. Gender-disaggregated monitoring indicators  will be developed to monitor the number of men and 
women  and  patients  served  by  the  health  care  center,  recruitment  of  community  health  workers,  volunteers,  and 
involvement of women in the PMU.  
 
The  capacity-building  project  components  will  focus  on  strengthening  the  abilities  of  partner  NGOs  and  official 
structures to deepen the understanding of the characteristics, needs, and dynamics of the urban poor, and to design 
effective  community  services  in  slums.  The  needs  of  women  and  girls  will  be  a  priority.  A  gender  specialist  will  be 
included  in  the  consulting  services  package  for  6  person-months,  and  a  full-time  officer  specializing  in  gender  and 
poverty  will  be  in  the  PMU  for  the  whole  project  period.  The  specialist  and  the  officer  will  work  with  the  PMU, 
partnership  agreements,  and  Local  Government  Division  to  turn  the  gender  into  an  action  plan.  The  action  plan  will 
include a budget, resources, and implementation schedule, and will be monitored regularly and adjusted accordingly.

GOOD GOVERNANCE AND ANTICORRUPTION MEASURES 

Good  governance  and  prevention  of  corruption  are  nonnegotiable  preconditions  for 
smooth, effective, efficient, and sustainable project implementation. In their absence, the urban 
poor—the main project beneficiaries—will be the main losers. Among others, the following steps 
are indicated in the Project to ensure good governance, which the Local Government Division 
and project management unit should proactively incorporate during implementation: 
 
Area 
Procurement 

Indicated Measures 

Follow Asian Development Bank (ADB) guidelines on procurement and consulting services. 

• 
•  Ensure transparent and competitive bidding process. 
•  Use funds only for authorized purposes, and adhere to procurement schedule. 
•  Ensure that contract packages are not split into small components.  
•  Be vigilant about the quality of procurement, and conduct regular field visits to check quality.  
•  Use information technology to increase transparency, accountability, and efficiency in 

procurement. 

Financial 
Management 

•  Regularly assess accounting and internal control systems to monitor expenditures and other 

financial transactions and safe custody of project-financed assets. 

•  Ensure that accounting and internal control systems are of acceptable standards. 
•  Ensure accounting information adheres to accounting standards acceptable to ADB and 

maintain substantial documentation. 

•  Submit audited and unaudited financial statements within an acceptable time limit. 
•  Conduct an independent audit acceptable to ADB. 
•  Pay special attention to stopping duplicate payments, tampering of invoices, adulteration of 

records, payments without supporting documents, misuse of funds, and payment of 
ineligible expenditures. 

•  Use information technology to ensure efficient and accountable financial management 

•  Establish process standards for timely payments to nongovernment organizations (NGOs) 

and other contractors, and regularly review adherence to the standards through 
performance audit. 

Social 
Control 

•  Conduct regular surveys of the quality of project services. 
•  Conduct a public relations campaign to inform and educate the beneficiaries about project 

systems. 

services. 

•  Establish links between Project and civil advocacy organizations. 
•  Ensure access to information at the health facilities and offices through notice boards, 

regular newsletters, a website, etc. 

•  Ensure effective functioning of joint government and civil-society bodies such as ward 

primary health care (PHC) committees, city corporations, municipality, and national health 
committees.  

•  Establish an effective grievance redress system and enable its effective functioning through 

wide publicity. 
Issue a citizen’s charter for the Project, and publicize it widely. 

• 
•  Use information technology to increase access to information and empower people. 

•  Establish oversight and supervisory mechanisms to detect fraud and corruption. 
•  Conduct annual financial disclosure of the project staff and regularly monitor project assets. 
•  Adhere to annual plans and explain deviations, if any, and carefully analyze unusual items. 
• 
•  Establish and follow a code of conduct for the Project, especially in dealing with NGOs. 
•  Regularly assess institutional capacities to respond and take measures to prevent 

Follow government guidelines on investigating corruption.
